Adakalanya pula diambil dari kata-kata lain yang tidak terdapat dalam surah itu tetapi menunjukkan dengan jelas isi surah tersebut, misalnya nama Surah al-Ikhlas/ 112. 

Ayat 112 dan 113 menyebutkan permintaan hidangan makanan dari langit oleh pengikut-pengikut Nabi Isa. Dalam beberapa bab dalam Perjanjian Baru dilukiskan sangat beragam (Matius vi.11, Kisah Para Rasul x.9-12 dan sebagainya).
text.115:
Dalam ayat ini diterangkan bahwa Allah mengabulkan doa tersebut dan menurunkan hidangan sesuai dengan permintaan mereka. Tetapi, dengan syarat bahwa sesudah turunnya hidangan itu, tidak boleh ada di antara mereka yang tetap kafir, atau kembali kafir sesudah beriman, karena mereka telah diberi pelajaran dan keterangan-keterangan tentang kekuasaan dan kebesaran Allah, kemudian diberi pula bukti nyata yang dapat mereka saksikan dengan panca indera mereka sendiri. Apabila masih ada di antara mereka yang kafir maka sepantasnya kemurkaan dan azab Allah ditimpakan kepada mereka, yang melebihi azab yang ditimpakan kepada orang-orang kafir lainnya.

Pendapat para ulama beragam mengenai macam makanan yang diturunkan Allah dalam hidangan tersebut. Tetapi masalah tersebut bukanlah masalah yang penting untuk dibicarakan, Al-Qur'an sendiri tidak menyebutkannya. Demikian pula Rasulullah saw. Yang perlu kita perhatikan ialah hubungan sebab akibat, serta isi dan tujuan dari kisah tersebut, untuk dijadikan iktibar dan pelajaran guna memperkokoh iman dan keyakinan kita kepada Allah dengan segala sifat-sifat kesempurnaan-Nya.
text.116:
Pada ayat ini, Allah berkata, apakah Isa dan ibunya telah menyatakan dirinya sebagai tuhan. Isa menyatakan bahwa pernyataan di atas adalah tidak benar, karena dia tidaklah berhak menyatakan sesuatu yang tidak patut bagi dirinya dan ibunya. Allah menanyakan hal demikian itu kepada Isa walaupun Allah mengetahui apa yang sebenarnya terjadi, agar Isa di hari Kiamat itu menyatakan di hadapan para rasul dan umat manusia bahwa hanya Allah-lah yang berhak disembah, serta dia menjelaskan kesalahan umatnya yang memandang dirinya dan ibunya sebagai Tuhan. Semua ibadah hanya ditujukan kepada Allah. Ayat ini memberikan peringatan kepada orang-orang Nasrani yang hidup kemudian atas kesalahan dan kekeliruan akidah mereka. Banyak macam ibadah dan doa yang dilakukan oleh orang Nasrani ditujukan kepada Isa dan ibunya, baik yang khusus untuk Isa dan ibunya masing-masing, maupun ibadah mempersekutukan mereka dengan Allah. Semua ibadah seperti itu tidak dapat dibenarkan, karena segala ibadah itu haruslah ditujukan kepada Allah saja. Firman Allah:

Padahal mereka hanya diperintah menyembah Allah dengan ikhlas menaati-Nya semata-mata karena (menjalankan) agama¦ (al-Bayyinah/98: 5)

Tiada Tuhan selain Allah yang berhak disembah hamba. Nabi Isa menjawab pertanyaan Allah tentang ibadah dan kepercayaan yang ditujukan kepada dirinya dan ibunya dengan jawaban yang diawali kata "Subhanaka" artinya "Engkau Mahasuci", maksudnya mustahil ada Tuhan selain Allah.

Nabi Isa menegaskan baik dirinya sendiri atau orang lain, tidaklah berhak untuk mengatakan sesuatu yang tidak patut bagi dirinya dan ibunya. Tidak terlintas sedikit pun dalam pikiran Nabi Isa untuk menyatakan dirinya atau ibunya sebagai tuhan, karena ia diutus kepada manusia untuk membimbing mereka ke jalan yang lurus yakni agama tauhid. Sekiranya Nabi Isa menyatakan pengakuannya sebagai Tuhan, atau terlintas dalam pikirannya, tentulah Allah lebih mengetahuinya, karena Dia Maha Mengetahui apa yang tersembunyi dalam pikiran manusia, terlebih apa yang diungkapkannya. Manusia tidak mengetahui apa yang disembunyikan Allah kecuali jika Dia memberitahukannya dengan perantaraan wahyu. Sesungguhnya hanya Allah sendiri yang Maha Mengetahui segala yang gaib; Ilmu-Nya meliputi segala yang pernah terjadi, yang sedang terjadi, dan yang akan terjadi.

Allah menanyakan apakah Nabi Isa menyatakan diri dan ibunya sebagai Tuhan, karena orang-orang Nasrani di Najran banyak yang menganggap Isa dan ibunya sebagai Tuhan (Alusi V;94). Yang penting ayat ini merupakan jawaban Nabi Isa yang dengan tegas tidak pernah menyatakan diri dan ibunya sebagai Tuhan. Jawaban ini perlu untuk diketahui oleh murid-murid Nabi Isa maupun semua pengikutnya.
text.117:
Sesudah Nabi Isa pada ayat yang lalu mensucikan Allah dan kemudian dia membersihkan dirinya dari tuduhan menganggap dirinya sebagai Tuhan, maka dalam ayat ini Isa menjelaskan apa sebenarnya yang telah diserukannya kepada kaumnya yaitu agar mereka menyembah Allah. Tuhannya sendiri dan juga Tuhan kaumnya. Tidak benar dia menuhankan dirinya dan ibunya karena mereka berdua adalah hamba Allah seperti juga manusia lainnya. Nabi Isa telah mengajarkan pokok-pokok agama dan dasar-dasar keimanan kepada kaumnya yang seharusnya mereka jadikan pedoman dalam kehidupan beragama sepanjang masa. Sewaktu Nabi Isa masih berada bersama mereka, beliau selalu memberikan bimbingan kepada mereka dan mengawasi segala tingkah laku mereka; yang benar dibenarkan, yang salah dinyatakan salah sesuai dengan petunjuk Allah. Tetapi setelah beliau diangkat ke langit, habislah masa tugas kerasulannya, putuslah pengawasan dan bimbingan beliau terhadap kaumnya. Nabi Isa tidak mengetahui lagi amal perbuatan mereka dan sejarah perkembangan mereka dan agamanya. Hanyalah Allah yang menjadi Pengawas dan Saksi atas mereka. Allah memberi petunjuk kepada orang yang menghendaki kebenaran, membiarkan orang yang menginginkan kesesatan. Orang yang menuhankan Isa telah kafir dan haram surga bagi mereka. Hal itu ditegaskan Allah dalam firman-Nya:

Sungguh, telah kafir orang-orang yang berkata, "Sesungguhnya Allah itu dialah Al-Masih putra Maryam." Padahal Al-Masih (sendiri) berkata, "Wahai Bani Israil! Sembahlah Allah, Tuhanku dan Tuhanmu." Sesungguhnya barang siapa mempersekutukan (sesuatu dengan) Allah, maka sungguh, Allah mengharamkan surga baginya, dan tempatnya ialah neraka. Dan tidak ada seorang penolong pun bagi orang-orang zalim itu. (al-Ma'idah/5:72)
text.118:
Ayat ini menerangkan bahwa Isa menyerahkan sepenuhnya keputusan atas orang-orang Nasrani itu kepada Allah, dan beliau berlepas tangan dari tanggung jawab atas perbuatan mereka, karena beliau sudah menyampaikan seruannya sesuai dengan perintah Allah, yaitu mengesakan-Nya serta mengkhususkan ibadah kepada-Nya. Allah akan menjatuhkan hukuman kepada mereka sesuai dengan perbuatan mereka. Dialah yang mengetahui siapa di antara mereka yang tetap dalam tauhid dan siapa yang musyrik, siapa pula yang taat dan siapa yang ingkar, siapa yang saleh dan yang fasik. Jika Allah menjatuhkan azab atas mereka, maka azab itu jatuh kepada orang yang memang patut menerima azab. Mereka itu adalah hamba-hamba Allah, seharusnya mereka itu menyembah Allah, tidak menyembah selain Allah. Jika Allah memberikan pengampunan kepada mereka, maka pengampunan itu diberikan-Nya kepada mereka yang patut diberi-Nya dan yang patut menerimanya. Allah Mahakuasa dan berwenang dalam mengurusi segala perkara, tidak ada orang lain yang turut mengurusinya. Allah Mahabijaksana dalam menentukan keputusan atas perkara itu, dan Dia Maha Mengetahui siapakah di antara orang-orang Nasrani yang telah menjadi musyrik dan siapa pula yang masih dalam agama tauhid.

Mereka yang menjadi musyrik, tidak ada ampunan bagi dosa mereka. Firman Allah:

Sesungguhnya Allah tidak akan mengampuni (dosa) karena mempersekutukan-Nya (syirik), dan Dia mengampuni apa (dosa) yang selain (syirik) itu bagi siapa yang Dia kehendaki. (an-Nisa'/4: 48)

Sejak permulaan abad masehi, sudah banyak aliran dalam kepercayaan yang tumbuh di kalangan penganut agama Nasrani. Sehingga banyak perselisihan yang timbul di antara mereka, maka semuanya terserah kepada Allah diazab atau diampuni di antara hamba-hamba-Nya sesuai dengan kehendak-Nya.
text.119: Dalam ayat ini, Allah menjelaskan bahwa pada hari Kiamat, orang yang senantiasa berbuat tetap dalam tauhid, akan memperoleh manfaat dari kebenaran iman mereka dan dari kejujuran perbuatan dan perkataan mereka. Kemanfaatan yang mereka peroleh itu ialah: pertama kenikmatan surga, kenikmatan yang banyak memberi kepuasan jasmaniah, dan kedua kenikmatan rida Ilahi, kenikmatan yang memberikan ketenteraman dan kepuasan rohani. Segala amal perbuatan mereka diterima Allah sebagai ibadah dan Allah memberi anugerah dan keridaan kepada mereka. Mereka merasa bahagia memperoleh keridaan dari Allah. Tidak ada kenikmatan yang lebih besar dari penghargaan dari Allah. Allah rida terhadap mereka, dan mereka rida terhadap Allah. Inilah puncak kebahagiaan abadi dalam diri manusia. Kedua nikmat Allah ini ialah surga dan rida Ilahi yang diperoleh sesudah melewati perhitungan amal pada hari Kiamat.
text.120: Surah ini diakhiri dengan pernyataan, bahwa segala kerajaan langit dan bumi beserta isinya hanyalah kepunyaan Allah. Baik makhluk yang berakal maupun yang tidak berakal; benda-benda mati ataupun makhluk bernyawa, semuanya tunduk dan takluk di bawah kudrat dan iradat-Nya. Ayat ini memperingatkan orang-orang Nasrani atas kesalahan cara berpikir mereka mengenai Isa dan ibunya, yang dianggap tuhan, padahal keduanya adalah hamba Allah dan milik-Nya. Keduanya bukan sekutu Allah, ataupun tandingan-Nya. Oleh karena itu, doa dan ibadah tidak selayaknya ditujukan kepada keduanya. Hanya Allah yang berhak disembah, karena Dialah pemilik dan penguasa alam ini beserta segala isinya.

en.name: The Table Spread
en.source: Aplikasi Quran Kementrian Agama Republik Indonesia

text.1:
The beginning of this verse commands every believer to fulfill the promises they have made, whether it be the covenant of servitude to Allah, or promises made between people, such as those related to marriage, trade, and so on, as long as the promise does not violate the Sharia of Allah, as mentioned in the hadith that reads:

"Every condition (binding promise) that does not conform to the Book of Allah is void, even if there are a hundred conditions." (Narrated by al-Bukhari and Muslim from Aisyah ra).

Furthermore, this verse mentions the animals that are lawful to eat, as mentioned in Surah al-Anam/6:143 and 144, and prohibits eating ten types of food as mentioned in the third verse of this Surah. Those who are in a state of ihram for Hajj and Umrah, or one of the two, are not permitted to hunt land game, whether in the sacred territory (tanah haram) or outside of it, and are not permitted to eat its meat. Even for those who are in the sacred territory but not in a state of ihram, it is not permissible to hunt land game. Thus, Allah establishes His law according to His will for the benefit of His servants.
text.2:
According to the narration of Ibn Juraij and Ikrimah, a man named al-Hutam al-Bakri came to Medina with camels carrying food supplies. After selling the food, he met the Prophet and pledged allegiance to embrace Islam. After he turned away and left, the Prophet observed him and said to his companions who were there: "He came to me with the face of a liar and turned away from me like a deceiver." After al-Hutam arrived in Yamamah, he apostatized from Islam. Subsequently, in the month of Zulkaidah, he went out again with his camels intending to sell food supplies to Mecca. When the Prophet's companions heard this news, some people from the Muhajirin and Ansar prepared to go out to confront him on the way, then this second verse was revealed.179 In the end, they did not do it.

In this second verse, Allah explains to the believers five important prohibitions that must not be violated, namely:

1.  Violating Allah's prohibitions, which means violating the practices and provisions established by Allah in the Hajj pilgrimage and other matters.

2.  Violating the sanctity of the sacred months, namely Zulkaidah, Zulhijah, Muharram and Rajab, during which it is forbidden to fight except in self-defense when attacked.

3.  Disturbing the *hadyu* animals, namely camels, cows and the like, goats, sheep and the like, which are offered to the Kaaba to draw closer to Allah, slaughtered in the sacred land, and their meat is given as a gift to the poor.

4.  Disturbing the *qalaid*, which are *hadyu* (sacrificial) animals that have been adorned with ropes, indicating that the animals are specifically prepared to be sacrificed and offered to the Kaaba. According to another opinion, this also includes people who wear necklaces indicating that they intend to visit the Kaaba, who must not be disturbed, as was done by the Arabs in the pre-Islamic era (*jahiliyah*).

5.  Hindering and disturbing people who visit Baitullah (the House of Allah) to seek Allah's bounty (sustenance) such as trading and seeking His pleasure, namely performing Hajj and Umrah. According to the majority (*jumhur*), those who must not be hindered are the believers, while non-believers are no longer allowed to enter the sacred land, according to Allah's saying:

"O you who have believed, indeed the polytheists are unclean, so let them not approach al-Masjid al-Haram after this, their [final] year." (at-Taubah/9:28).

Furthermore, the verse explains that if one has already performed *tahallul*, meaning after completing the Hajj or Umrah pilgrimage, it is permissible to hunt outside the sacred land, while it remains impermissible in the sacred land, it is forbidden to uproot plants and disturb its game, to commit injustice against those who hinder entry to al-Masjid al-Haram, such as the polytheists hindering the believers from performing Umrah as stipulated in the Treaty of Hudaibiyah. Then the last part of this verse obligates the believers to help one another in doing good and being pious, for their own benefit and happiness. It is forbidden to help one another in committing sins and transgressions, and it commands to remain pious to Allah in order to avoid His very severe punishment.
text.3:
In this verse, the foods that are forbidden are explained, namely:

1. Carrion, which is an animal that dies without being slaughtered. Among the wisdoms behind the prohibition of carrion is that it contains germs that are very harmful to health, in addition to its repulsive state.

2. Blood, which is blood that flows out of an animal's body, whether from slaughter or other causes. The wisdom behind the prohibition of blood is, among other things, that it contains germs and dirty substances from the body and is difficult to digest.

3. Pork, including all parts of its body.

4. Animals slaughtered by mentioning or glorifying names other than Allah, such as mentioning the names of idols. The wisdom behind its prohibition is because it associates partners with Allah.

5. Animals that die by strangulation. Many opinions explain what is meant by dying by strangulation, which includes dying because of being tied up and so on, so that the animal dies in a helpless state. The wisdom behind its prohibition is the same as the wisdom behind the prohibition of carrion.

6. Animals that die from being beaten, which are animals that die from being beaten with hard or heavy objects. The wisdom behind its prohibition, according to some opinions, is because its blood does not come out, thus spoiling the meat. Apart from that, there is also a prohibition against mistreating animals, and this act is clearly considered a violation of the Prophet's hadith which reads:

From Syaddad bin Aus, the Messenger of Allah (saw) said, "Allah has obligated doing good (ihsan) upon everything. If you kill, kill well, and if you slaughter, slaughter well. Let one of you sharpen his knife and not torture the animal he is slaughtering." (Narrated by Ahmad, Muslim and Ashabus-Sunan).

7. Animals that die from falling from a high place, such as falling from the top of a hill into a ravine. The wisdom behind its prohibition is the same as carrion.

8. Animals that die from being gored by other animals. The wisdom is the same as carrion. If there is still time to slaughter it, then it is halal (permissible).

9. Animals that die from being mauled by wild animals. The wisdom is the same as carrion, if there is still time to slaughter it, then it is halal (permissible).

10. Animals that are slaughtered for idols, as was done by the Arabs in the days of ignorance who slaughtered animals near idols, which numbered 360, located around the Kaaba. The wisdom behind its prohibition is because this act includes associating partners with Allah.

Furthermore, it is explained about the prohibition of drawing lots with arrows, as was done by the Arabs in the days of ignorance, namely by taking three arrows that did not yet have feathers, one of the arrows was written with the words: "Amarani rabbi" (My Lord has commanded me), the second arrow was written with the words: "Nahani rabbi" (My Lord has forbidden me), while the third arrow was not written with anything. The arrows were kept inside the Kaaba. If they intended to do a great and important job, they would ask the caretaker of the Kaaba to pull out one of the three arrows and carry out what was written on the arrow that was taken. If the arrow that was taken was the one that was not written with anything, then the lottery was repeated. This act is prohibited because it contains shirk (associating partners with Allah) or superstition and myths. In this case, according to the teachings of the Messenger of Allah (saw), if you want to choose one of two equally important jobs or choose between doing or not doing something, then you should perform the istikharah prayer of two rak'ahs. If an ordinary lottery (qur'ah) does not contain wickedness or superstition and myths, it is not prohibited, such as a lottery to take one part of two piles that have been made equally numerous, who is entitled to each pile, then a qur'ah (lottery) is held.

Furthermore, it is explained that at the Farewell Pilgrimage (Haji Wada), the disbelievers had given up in their efforts to defeat the Islamic religion. Therefore, the Muslims should not be afraid of them but should fear Allah.

Furthermore, in this verse, something important for the Prophet Muhammad (saw) and for the entire Muslim community is explained again, that Allah has perfected the Islamic religion and has completed His blessings, and has approved of the Islamic religion as the religion of mankind.

After this verse was recited by the Prophet, Umar wept, then the Prophet asked what caused him to weep. Umar replied, "Something that is already perfect has nothing left to wait for except its decrease." The Messenger of Allah confirmed Umar's words (Narrated by Ibn Jarir and Harun bin Antarah from his father). It is narrated that this verse was revealed in Arafah on the 9th of Zulhijjah 10 H, on a Friday after Asr. History has recorded: that 81 days after the revelation of this verse, the Prophet Muhammad (saw) died after carrying out his mission for approximately 23 years. Indeed, the teachings of Islam are perfect, even though all matters have not been detailed, but they are perfect enough with various principles of worldly and hereafter affairs.

Then, at the end of this verse, it is explained that people who are forced to eat food that Allah has forbidden because of hunger without intending to sin are allowed to do so, as long as they eat only what is necessary, just to sustain life. Indeed, Allah is Most Forgiving, Most Merciful.
text.4:
This verse explains two types of food that are permissible:

1.  Good food, which is all types of food that stimulate the appetite to eat it and there is no *nas* (explicit textual evidence) prohibiting it. As for that which already has a stipulation of prohibition, then that stipulation must be obeyed, such as the saying of the Prophet Muhammad (peace and blessings be upon him):

    From Ibn Abbas, who said, "The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) forbade eating every beast of prey with fangs and every bird with sharp claws." (Narrated by Ahmad, Muslim, and Ashabus-Sunan).

2.  Game animals caught by trained hunting animals, so that the game is immediately brought to its owner and will not be eaten unless given by its owner. If the hunting animal eats the game first, before being given by its owner, then the game is forbidden to be eaten, like the prohibition of carrion.

Furthermore, this verse explains that the spoils of trained hunting animals are permissible to eat if, when releasing the animal, the hunter recites the *basmalah* (Bismillahir Rahmanir Rahim - In the name of Allah, the Most Gracious, the Most Merciful). The ruling on reciting the *basmalah* is obligatory according to some scholars, such as Abu Hanifah; according to Imam Shafi'i, the ruling is *sunnah* (recommended).

Then, the end of this verse explains to remain in *taqwa* (God-consciousness), which is to obey all of Allah's commands and avoid His prohibitions, because Allah is very quick in reckoning all the deeds of His servants, without anything being left behind or hidden from Him.
text.5:
This verse explains three kinds of things that are permissible for believers, namely:

1.  Good and wholesome food, as intended in the fourth verse. It is then mentioned again in this verse to reinforce the meaning of "good" and to explain that the permissibility of eating good and wholesome food does not change.

2.  The food of the People of the Book (Ahli Kitab). According to the majority of scholars (jumhur ulama), "food" here refers to the slaughtered animals of the Jews and Christians, because they at that time had the belief that it was forbidden to eat animals slaughtered by mentioning a name other than Allah. As long as they still hold such a belief, their slaughtered animals remain permissible. As for other foods such as fruits, etc., the ruling is simply referred back to the first type, namely *tayyibat* (good and wholesome); if they are included in the category of good and wholesome food, they are permissible to eat; if not (*khabais* - impure), they are forbidden to eat. As for the slaughtered animals of non-Ahli Kitab disbelievers, they are forbidden to eat.

3.  Marrying free women (not slaves), and believing women, and women of the People of the Book is permissible. According to some commentators (mufasir), *al-muhsanat* refers to women who guard their chastity.

Men are allowed to marry these women with the obligation to provide for them, as long as there are no other intentions hidden in their hearts, such as taking them for adultery or as concubines. In short, a believing man may marry women of the People of the Book with the conditions mentioned above. However, Muslim women are not allowed to marry men of the People of the Book, let alone disbelieving men who are not Ahlil Kitab. Then, the end of the fifth verse warns that whoever disbelieves after having believed, all the good deeds they have ever done will be erased, and in the Hereafter they will be among the losers.
text.7: In this verse, Allah commands the Muslims to remember His blessings, namely the religious regulations that have been established for them. With the advent of Islam, animosity disappeared, and brotherhood arose. After that, Allah reminds them of the covenant that was once pledged, which is the promise to be obedient and devoted to the Prophet Muhammad (peace and blessings be upon him) in times of hardship and ease, to follow all his commands and to abandon all his prohibitions with full obedience and devotion. At the end of this verse, Allah commands the Muslims to remain mindful of Allah (taqwa), to guard against forgetting His blessings, and to avoid breaking the promises that have been pledged, both openly and secretly. For Allah is All-Knowing of everything that is hidden in the hearts of mankind.
text.8:
This verse commands the believers to carry out their deeds and work meticulously, honestly, and sincerely for Allah, whether the work is related to religious matters or worldly affairs. Only in this way can they succeed and obtain the results or rewards they expect. In testimony, they must be fair in stating the truth, regardless of who the person is, even if it benefits the opponent and harms friends and relatives. This verse is in line with Surah an-Nisa/4:135, which similarly explains about someone who acts justly and honestly in testimony. The difference is that in that verse, the obligation to act justly and honestly in testimony is explained even if the testimony will harm oneself, mother, father, and relatives, while in this verse, it is explained that hatred towards a certain group should not encourage someone to give unfair and dishonest testimony, even against opponents.

Furthermore, broadly and comprehensively, Allah commands the believers to act justly, because justice is needed in all things, to achieve and obtain peace, prosperity, and happiness in this world and the hereafter. Therefore, acting justly is the closest path to achieving the goal of being pious to Allah.

The end of this verse states Allah's promise that those believers who do many righteous deeds will be given forgiveness and a great reward. Allah's promise will surely be fulfilled, as stated in His word:

"Indeed, Allah does not fail in His promise." (Ali 'Imran/3:9).

*Amal saleh* (righteous deeds) is every good, beneficial, and appropriate work to be done, whether it is *ubudiyah* (acts of worship) such as *salat* (prayer) and others, or work such as helping the poor, caring for orphans, and other social actions.
text.9:
This verse commands the believers to carry out their deeds and work diligently, honestly, and sincerely for Allah, whether the work is related to religious matters or matters of worldly life. Because only in this way can they succeed and obtain the results or rewards they expect. In testimony, they must be fair in stating the truth, regardless of who the person is, even if it benefits the opponent and harms friends and relatives. This verse is in line with Surah an-Nisa/4:135, which both explain about a person who acts justly and honestly in testimony. The difference is that in that verse, the obligation to act justly and honestly in testimony is explained even if the testimony will harm oneself, mother, father, and relatives, while in this verse, it is explained that hatred towards a certain group should not encourage a person to give unfair and dishonest testimony, even against opponents.

Furthermore, broadly and comprehensively, Allah commands the believers to act justly, because justice is needed in all things, to achieve and obtain peace, prosperity, and happiness in this world and the hereafter. Therefore, acting justly is the closest path to achieving the goal of being mindful of Allah (taqwa).

The end of this verse states Allah's promise that those believers who do many good deeds will be given forgiveness and a great reward. Allah's promise will surely be fulfilled, as stated in His word:

"Indeed, Allah does not fail in His promise." (Ali 'Imran/3:9).

Good deeds (amal saleh) are every good, beneficial, and appropriate work to be done, both acts of worship (ubudiyah) such as prayer (salat) and others, as well as works such as helping the poor, caring for orphans, and other social actions.
text.10: Furthermore, that verse states that the disbelievers who deny the verses of Allah are the inhabitants of Hell. The verses of Allah mean the signs of the existence of Allah, the One and Only, and the Al-Qur'an. Every verse that is a great miracle for the prophethood and apostleship of Muhammad (saw) is a sign of the existence of Allah, the One and Only, the All-Powerful. The end of the verse states that the disbelievers who deny and reject His verses are the inhabitants of Hell.
text.11:
Those who believe must remember the immense favor bestowed upon them by His power, Allah has restrained and freed them from a very dangerous evil planned by the disbelievers.

Many narrations tell about the reason for the revelation of this verse, which generally revolves around a man from the Muharib tribe who was sent by his people to kill the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him). The strongest narration is the one strengthened by al-Hakim from the hadith of Jabir, namely a man from the Muharib tribe named Gauras bin Haris came and stood before the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) while (drawing his sword) and said, "Who can protect you?" The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) answered, "Allah." Then the sword fell from his hand and was taken by the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) who said, "Who can protect you?" The man answered, "Be the best of those who act." The Messenger of Allah asked, "Will you acknowledge that there is no god but Allah and that I am His Messenger?" The man answered, "I promise that I will not fight you and will not join those who will fight you." Then the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) released him, after he returned to his people he said to them: "I have just come to meet the best of men, namely the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him)."

This verse invites those who believe to remember the favor that will be given to them when facing people who intend evil, Allah restrains and releases them from the danger of enemy evil.

According to some commentators, the evil referred to in this verse is the evil of Gauras mentioned above. Others are of the opinion that what is meant is all the evil done by the disbelievers to the Messenger of Allah and his companions at the beginning of the birth of Islam and they were always protected by Allah.

Remembering such things is very beneficial for the lives of those who believe, it will further strengthen their faith in Allah and His power and generate enthusiasm and self-confidence in facing difficulties and suffering to uphold the truth. At the end of this verse, Allah commands the believers to remain pious to Him who has shown His power in helping and protecting them from the evil of the enemy. Allah commands the Muslims to put their trust in Him, after they have made efforts and endeavors according to their abilities, and forbids them from putting their trust in anyone other than Allah.
text.12: According to narrations, the Jewish people's breaking of their promise occurred after they were freed from Pharaoh's grip in Egypt. Then, Allah, through the Prophet Musa (Moses), commanded them to leave Egypt and go to Palestine. At that time, Palestine was inhabited by the Canaanite tribe, who were very powerful and arrogant. They were ordered to wage jihad against these harsh people with a promise that Allah would help them. Allah commanded the Prophet Musa to take 12 leaders representing each tribe from among them to carry out the task ordered by Allah. After the agreement was made, they set out, and upon arriving near the holy land of Jerusalem, the Prophet Musa ordered the 12 leaders to enter the city in disguise to spy and obtain the necessary information. (Book of Numbers xiii and xiv. See also al-Baqarah/2:63 and its tafsir). After the Jewish leaders saw the inhabitants who were strong and possessed great power, they became afraid, returned, and told their people about what they had seen, even though they had been ordered by the Prophet Musa not to tell their people what they had seen. Thus, they broke their promise, except for two of the leaders, as mentioned in verse 23 of this surah. In addition, Allah commanded them again to establish prayer (salat), pay zakat, believe in and help the Messengers of Allah who would be sent after Musa, such as Daud (David), Sulaiman (Solomon), Zakaria (Zechariah), Yahya (John), Isa (Jesus), and Muhammad. Besides that, Allah also commanded them to give a good loan to Allah, which is to spend their wealth sincerely in the way of Allah. If they were willing to carry out all of Allah's commands, then Allah would surely erase their other sins and admit them into gardens beneath which rivers flow. Whoever remains a disbeliever (kafir) and breaks the promise after that, then they are the ones who have strayed from the right path.
text.13:
This verse explains that the Jews were always breaking their promises, so Allah cursed them and hardened their hearts. Allah also explains that they did not hesitate to alter the words of Allah from the Torah revealed to Prophet Musa (Moses), even though Prophet Musa had taken a covenant from them to preserve and implement its contents. However, none of them implemented it as the Muslims preserved the Qur'an during the time of Prophet Muhammad (saw). The original Torah, as stated by Jewish and Christian historians, had disappeared since the Babylonian kingdom attacked their city, burned their temple, and captured the surviving Jews.

Furthermore, Allah explains that the Jews had forgotten a part of what they had been reminded of, and deliberately did not do some of what was commanded, because it had become their habit to rebel and break promises. According to Ibn Abbas and Mujahid, they forgot a part of the original Torah. And this could happen to the Jews after the loss of the original Torah, because none of them memorized it. The Torah is not the same as the Old Testament. Likewise, the Gospel is not the same as the New Testament.

At the end of this verse, Allah warns Prophet Muhammad (saw) that indeed, such was the character and behavior of the Jews in the past towards Allah, the Books, and His Messengers. Allah warns that Prophet Muhammad (saw) will always face various kinds of deception and betrayal from them. Do not think that the Prophet is safe because the Prophet has agreed to live peacefully alongside them, because it is their nature to always oppose and break promises, except for a small number of them, such as Abdullah bin Salam and his companions who had sincerely embraced Islam and became praiseworthy companions of the Messenger of Allah. In dealing with these people, Prophet Muhammad should not worry, but should forgive the mistakes they have made. Indeed, Allah loves those who do good.
text.14:
This verse explains that Allah took a covenant from those who claimed to be Christians to obey and adhere to what Allah commanded and forbade, and to follow His Prophets. However, they deliberately forgot a portion of what they were reminded of in the Gospel (Injil), meaning they did not act upon some of what was warned in the Gospel. This is because the first followers of Prophet Isa Almasih (Jesus Christ) were from the common people, and his loyal companions consisted of hunters who were constantly driven away and antagonized by the Jews. They did not yet have the social power to record and preserve what they had memorized from the Gospel, and many books were written by them which were called Gospels, as explained in the holy books and history of their church.

The end of this verse explains that because of the behavior of the Christians who did not want to fulfill the covenant, Allah caused division among themselves until the Day of Judgment. In the Hereafter, Allah will inform them of all the mistakes they made in the world, so that they can no longer escape punishment.
text.15:
This verse explains that the Prophet Muhammad has come to clarify some of what they concealed regarding God's law mentioned in the Torah. Among what the Prophet clarified were matters such as the reckoning of deeds and their recompense on the Day of Judgment, and the law of stoning (rajam). However, much was also left unsaid because it was considered less important, such as matters concerning the coming of Muhammad saw as the final Prophet and his characteristics.

What motivated them to conceal what they knew from the Torah was the fear of losing their position, influence, and other worldly matters, including a feeling that never left them: that they were descendants or the people of the best Prophet, namely the descendants of Prophet Isaac, while Prophet Muhammad saw was a descendant of Prophet Ismail.

The Prophet Muhammad's state of being ummi (illiterate, unable to read and write) further emboldened them to conceal what they wanted to conceal, because they thought the Prophet Muhammad would not know it. However, their assumption was wrong with the revelation (Al-Qur'an) to the Prophet, which revealed some of what they had concealed, causing many Jewish priests to convert to Islam. The law of stoning (rajam) that the Jews concealed from the Prophet Muhammad saw still exists today in the book of Deuteronomy xxii.22-24: A married woman or man found sleeping together "both of them shall die." And if the one who does that is "a virgin, then you shall bring them both out to the gate of that city and stone them to death."

Furthermore, the meaning of "there has come to you from Allah a light and a clear Book" is explained. What is meant by "light" here is the Prophet Muhammad saw because he has illuminated mankind from the realm of ignorance to the realm of faith and knowledge. While what is meant by "a clear Book" here is the Al-Qur'an, which explains God's law revealed to Muhammad and also explains the secrets of the People of the Book who like to change and conceal parts of the contents of the Torah and the Gospel.
text.16:
This verse explains that through the Qur'an, Allah guides those who follow His pleasure to the path of salvation in this world and the hereafter, bringing them out of the realm of darkness into the realm of light, and guiding them to the right path.

This verse explains three kinds of guidance that are of great benefit, namely:

a. Obeying the teachings of the Qur'an will lead people to safety and happiness.

b. Obeying the teachings of the Qur'an will free people from all kinds of errors caused by superstition and *khurafat* (myths/folklore).

c. Obeying the Qur'an will lead people to the ultimate goal of religion, which is happiness in this world and happiness in the hereafter.
text.17:
Generally, the Christian creed is *taslis* (trinity), namely the Father, the Son, and the Holy Spirit. This creed is difficult for anyone to understand well, even with all kinds of interpretations given by Christian scholars, past and present. *Tafsir al-Manar* explains that the main pillar of the Christian creed is the statement found at the beginning of the Book of John.

In this verse, Allah states firmly that those who say that Allah is Al-Masih, the son of Maryam, have become disbelievers. Then Allah provides reasons with signs to refute the convoluted arguments of the Christians:

Say, "Then who could prevent Allah if He willed to destroy the Messiah, the son of Mary, and his mother and everyone on earth entirely?" And to Allah belongs the dominion of the heavens and the earth and whatever is between them. He creates what He wills, and Allah is over all things competent. (al-Ma'idah/5:17).
text.18:
According to the narration of Ibn Ishaq, Ibn Abbas narrated that the Messenger of Allah came to Numan bin Ada, Bahri bin 'Amar and Syas bin 'Adi. After a discussion between the Messenger of Allah and them, the Messenger of Allah invited them to embrace Islam and warned them of Allah's punishment, so they said, "Do not frighten us, O Muhammad: By Allah, we are the sons of Allah and His beloved ones," then this verse was revealed.

The words of the Jews and Christians were refuted by Allah, meaning, "Say, O Muhammad, to them: if you are truly the sons of Allah and His beloved ones who possess special privileges more than others, as you assume, why does Allah punish you for your sins in the world as you have suffered greatly, both regarding your places of worship, your country, your kingdom, and others, because a father will not punish his children and will not punish his beloved ones. Therefore, you are not the sons of Allah and neither are you His beloved ones who possess special privileges as you assume, but you are ordinary human beings and servants of Allah like other human beings. Allah will forgive the sins of His servants for whom He deems worthy of forgiveness and punish those who deserve to be punished according to His will, because Allah is the One who possesses the kingdom of the heavens and the earth and what is between them."
text.19:
According to the narration of Ibn Ishaq, Ibn Abbas narrated the *sabab nuzul* (reason for revelation) of this verse: the Messenger of Allah invited the Jews to embrace Islam, but they refused. Then Mu'adh bin Jabal, Sa'ad bin 'Ubadah, and 'Uqbah bin Wahab said to them: "O Jews, fear Allah, indeed Muhammad is the Messenger." Then Rafi'i bin Murairah and Wahab bin Yahuza said, "We never said that to you, and Allah did not send down a book after Musa, nor did He send a messenger after him to bring good tidings or to warn," so this verse was revealed.

In this verse, Allah explains to the People of the Book that the Messenger of Allah whom they were waiting for has indeed come, in accordance with what they knew from the books given by Allah through His Messengers Musa and Isa (peace be upon them). That Messenger of Allah who has come explains the *sharia* of Allah, during the period called "Fatrah," which is between Nabi Isa and Nabi Muhammad; during that time, revelation did not descend, while the contents of the Torah and the Gospel had become largely obscure and not widely known; and much of what remained had undergone changes or been forgotten, whether intentionally or unintentionally. Now the Messenger of Allah, namely Muhammad (peace be upon him), has come, bringing good tidings and warnings to explain everything needed for worldly and afterlife life, showing the right path that must be taken by mankind, so there is no longer any reason for them to say that they do not know because there is no messenger to guide and bring good tidings and warnings. Now the People of the Book and all of mankind must determine their stance. If they want to be safe and happy in this world and the hereafter, then they must believe in Muhammad, the last Messenger of Allah, and follow all his guidance and commands. Whoever rebels, then he alone will bear the consequences, and no one else will help him. Whoever does not believe in Allah and all the messengers He sent before, then they will feel a painful torment from Allah.
text.20:
In this verse, Prophet Muhammad is commanded to remember the event experienced by Moses when he commanded his people to always remember and be grateful for Allah's blessings in the correct way. Allah's blessings that are gratefully received will surely receive additions from Him. Conversely, His blessings that are denied are threatened with punishment. Among these blessings are:

a. Allah has raised so many prophets from the Children of Israel, such as Prophet Moses, Prophet Aaron, and others.

b. Allah made the Children of Israel free and independent, managing their own affairs, so that in that state it was as if they had full sovereignty.

c. Allah gave them things that had never been given to others, for example, when they were chased by Pharaoh and his soldiers and faced a dead end, at that time Allah split the sea so that they were saved from Pharaoh's pursuit. But after they passed and Pharaoh and his soldiers followed, the road turned back into the sea, so that Pharaoh and his soldiers drowned. Allah gave *mann* (a sweet food like honey) and *salwa* (a type of quail). And when they were in the desert in a very hot state, Allah sent thick clouds to shade them. These are the blessings given to them to be grateful for.
text.21:
After Prophet Musa reminded the Jewish people and explained those blessings, he then commanded them to bravely face the enemies of Allah with the promise that Allah would help them. Prophet Musa's command was that they should enter the holy land of Canaan (Palestine) and reside in the land that Allah had promised and designated as their dwelling place.

According to a narration by Ibn 'Asakir from Mu'adh bin Jabal, the holy land is between the Tigris and Euphrates rivers. The land is called holy because so many prophets have inhabited it, constantly inviting people to the religion of Tawhid, therefore the land is clean from idols and misguided beliefs. And Prophet Musa forbade them from apostatizing back to idol worship and creating chaos in society by committing injustice and following their desires. If they did not obey these provisions, they would be at a loss, because the blessings that had been given to them would be revoked and nullified.
text.22:
After Prophet Musa and his people approached that prosperous land, he commanded his people to enter the holy land and be prepared to face its inhabitants. Because Prophet Musa's people felt weak, lowly, and afraid, they refused to enter the holy land, even wanting to return to Egypt because the inhabitants of the holy land were cruel and harsh people. They declared to Prophet Musa that they would not enter the holy land as long as its cruel inhabitants were still there; only if the inhabitants had left the holy land would they be willing to enter it. (In the Book of Numbers xiii. 32-33 it is mentioned 'a land that devours its inhabitants and is inhabited by giants').

From the answer of Prophet Musa's people, it can be concluded that they were very weak in spirit and lacked steadfastness. They did not want to obtain happiness and achieve glory through struggle. They wanted to obtain it without struggle. A people with such an attitude and stance will not obtain glory, pleasure, happiness, and prosperity. Regarding the fertility and prosperity of Canaan, an ancient land bordering the Dead Sea and the Jordan River in the area of Palestine at that time, and the condition of its inhabitants who were strong and mighty, was acknowledged by the followers of Prophet Musa who were sent there.
text.23: After the attitude of the people of Prophet Musa (Moses) regarding entering the holy land and residing in it was revealed, two messengers from the people of Prophet Musa, who were indeed pious towards Allah and had been given blessings and obtained His pleasure, encouraged their companions to immediately enter the gate of Baitulmaqdis. (These two righteous men were Joshua son of Nun and Caleb son of Jephunneh, who are recounted at length in Numbers 13 and 14). If they entered it, they would surely be victorious and be able to expel its strong inhabitants. Because that victory would be obtained through the help of Allah, which had been promised and would surely be fulfilled.
text.24: The encouragement of the two messengers could not influence their people and did not change their spirit. Therefore, after that encouragement, they repeated their statement to Prophet Musa that they would never enter Canaan as long as the giants and arrogant inhabitants of that land were still there. They emphasized that if Prophet Musa still intended to enter the land of Canaan, then let Prophet Musa alone, with the help of God, fight those people, while they would remain disobedient and not follow Musa into Canaan. This answer of theirs shows their shallowness of thought and their pettiness. Indeed, they had initially worshipped Allah following Prophet Musa, then they tried to worship the calf following the invitation of Samiri. Indeed, the Jewish people were accustomed to disobeying their Prophet, even sometimes killing him.
text.25: After Prophet Musa's (Moses) invitation was disobeyed by his people, and they even rejected it, Prophet Musa expressed his complaint to Allah that he could not control his people. Therefore, Musa a.s. (peace be upon him) pleaded to Allah that he and his brother be separated on one side, and his people on the other, and pleaded to Allah to give a just decision. So, if his wicked people were to be punished, Prophet Musa and his brothers should be saved from that punishment.
text.26:
The prayer of Prophet Musa (Moses) was answered by Allah, and Allah declared that indeed the holy land was forbidden to them for forty years. Because of that disobedience, they could not enter the holy land and could not inhabit it for forty years. During that time, they were always in a state of confusion, not knowing direction or purpose. After that, Allah encouraged Prophet Musa not to feel sad about the misfortune/punishment that befell his wicked people, because for them it would be a lesson and an experience.

According to the opinion of most Quranic commentators (mufassirun), Prophet Musa and Prophet Harun (Aaron) were in the desert together with the people of Bani Israil (Children of Israel), but for Prophet Musa and Prophet Harun, that desert was a place of rest and increased their rank. Meanwhile, for the disbelieving Jews, it was a very severe punishment. After the events in the barren Paran desert were over, Prophet Musa and Prophet Harun passed away. The purity of the fitrah (natural disposition) of the Bani Israil had been corrupted by the misguidance, enslavement, oppression, and coercion of the kings of Egypt, until they became misguided, cowardly, and fearful. This had become ingrained in them. Therefore, when Musa a.s. (peace be upon him) led them towards truth, courage, and happiness, they remained cowardly.
text.27:
The Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) was commanded to recite the story of the two sons of Adam (peace be upon him), when they offered a sacrifice, and the sacrifice of one was accepted while the other's was not. The one whose sacrifice was not accepted resolved to kill his brother, while the one threatened responded that he submitted to Allah, because Allah only accepts sacrifices from those who are righteous.

According to the narration of Ibn Abbas, Ibn Umar, and others, Adam's son named Qabil (Cain) had agricultural land, and his son named Habil (Abel) had a goat farm. Both sons of Adam had twin sisters. At that time, Allah revealed to Adam that Qabil should be married to Habil's twin sister. Qabil was unhappy and angry with this marriage, as Habil's twin sister was more beautiful. Both of them wanted the beautiful sister. Finally, Adam instructed Qabil and Habil to offer a sacrifice to find out whose sacrifice would be accepted. Qabil sacrificed from his agricultural produce, and what he gave was of low quality, while Habil sacrificed with his best choice of goat. Allah accepted Habil's sacrifice, which meant that Habil was justified in marrying Qabil's twin sister. Thus, Qabil's anger and envy increased, so he resolved to kill his brother. The sign of an accepted sacrifice was that the sacrifice was consumed by fire until it was completely gone. 197)

From this event, we can learn that what is spent should not merely be to expect praise and flattery, but should be done sincerely so that it is accepted by Allah.
text.28:
This verse obligates us to respect the sanctity of human life and prohibits bloodshed. Then Allah explains that Abel would not retaliate against Cain's challenge because of his fear of Allah. Abel had no intention of answering Cain's challenge, because he considered it contrary to the characteristics of the pious, and he did not want to bear the sin of murder. The Messenger of Allah said:

From Abi Bakrah, the Messenger of Allah (saw) said, "If two Muslims fight each other with their swords, and one kills the other, then both the killer and the killed will enter Hell." The Messenger of Allah was asked: "The killer is clear (his ruling), but what about the one who was killed?" The Prophet replied, "(He also enters Hell) because he also tried hard to kill his friend." (Narrated by Ahmad, al-Bukhari, al-Baihaqi and al-Hakim).
text.29: In this verse, Habil gives an answer to Qabil that Habil surrenders himself to Allah and does not want to challenge him so that all sins, both Qabil's sins and other sins after that, are borne by Qabil himself. Habil based his statement on three very important things. First, that acceptable deeds are only from those who are *taqwa* (God-fearing). Second, Habil will not kill anyone, because he fears Allah. And third, Habil does not resist, because he fears sin that will result in entering hell.
text.30:
Initially, Cain was afraid to kill Abel, but his passionate anger constantly pushed and deceived him, until courage arose to kill his brother, and he carried out his intention without thinking about the consequences. After this actually happened, as a result, Cain became a loser in this world and the hereafter. In this world, he lost because he killed his pious and devout brother. And in the hereafter, he will lose because he will not obtain the blessings of the hereafter that are prepared for the muttaqin (those who are conscious of God).

Imam as-Suddi narrated from Ibn Abbas, from Murrah bin Abdillah, and from several companions of the Prophet Muhammad saw that after Cain was deceived by his desires and resolved to kill his brother, he searched for Abel and found him on a mountain tending sheep, but he was sleeping. So Cain took a large stone and dropped it on him in an open place called Arak.
text.31:
This murder was the first to occur among the children of Adam. Cain, as the murderer, did not know what to do with his murdered brother (Abel), and he felt displeased to see his brother's corpse lying on the ground. Then Allah sent a raven scratching the ground with its claws to show Cain how to bury his brother's corpse.

After Cain witnessed what the raven had done, he understood what he had to do with his brother's corpse. At that time, Cain felt his foolishness as to why he could not do as the raven did, and then bury his brother. Because of this, Cain greatly regretted his wrong actions. From this event, we can learn that humans sometimes gain knowledge and experience from what has happened around them. Regret can be repentance as long as it is driven by fear of Allah and regret for the bad consequences of his actions. The Messenger of Allah said,

"Regret is repentance." (Narrated by Ahmad, al-Bukhari, al-Baihaqi and al-Hakim).

No one is killed unjustly except that the first son of Adam receives a portion of the sin because he was the first to commit murder. (Narrated by al-Bukhari and Muslim).

(32) This verse explains a provision that killing one human being means killing all human beings, just as preserving the life of one human being means preserving the life of all human beings. This verse shows the necessity of the unity of the ummah and the obligations of each of them towards the other, namely, to maintain the safety of life and communal life and to avoid things that endanger others. This can be felt because the needs of every human being cannot be met by themselves, so they greatly need to help each other, especially in matters concerning the public interest. Indeed, the Children of Israel had so many messengers come to them with clear explanations, but many of them transgressed the limits by committing corruption on earth. Finally, they lost the honor, wealth, and power that they had all possessed in the past.
text.32:
This murder was the first to occur among the children of Adam. Cain, as the murderer, did not know what to do with his murdered brother (Abel), and he felt displeased seeing his brother's corpse lying on the ground. Then Allah sent a raven that scratched the ground with its claws to show Cain how to bury his brother's corpse.

After Cain witnessed what the raven had done, he understood what he had to do with his brother's corpse. At that time, Cain felt his foolishness, wondering why he could not do what the raven did, and then bury his brother. Because of this, Cain greatly regretted his wrong action. From this event, we can learn that humans sometimes gain knowledge and experience from what has happened around them. Regret can be repentance as long as it is driven by fear of Allah and regret for the bad consequences of his actions. The Messenger of Allah said,

"Regret is repentance." (Narrated by Ahmad, al-Bukhari, al-Baihaqi and al-Hakim).

No one is killed unjustly but the first son of Adam receives a share of the sin because he was the first to commit murder. (Narrated by al-Bukhari and Muslim).
text.33: Those who disturb security and disrupt peace, obstruct the implementation of law, justice, and sharia, damage public interests such as destroying livestock, damaging agriculture, and so on, they can be killed, crucified, have their hands and feet cut off on opposite sides, or be exiled. According to the majority (jumhur), the death penalty is carried out against those who disturb security, commit robbery, and the like, accompanied by murder; the punishment of crucifixion until death is carried out against those who disturb security accompanied by murder and seizure of property; the punishment of cutting off hands is for those who commit seizure of property. As for the punishment for those who disturb security accompanied by threats and intimidation, it is exile. There is an opinion that says that the punishment of exile means imprisonment or can be replaced with imprisonment. The punishment in this verse is determined to be so severe because, in terms of the security disturbance in question, it is not only aimed at the public but also often results in murder, robbery, destruction, and so on. Therefore, these crimes should not be forgiven by anyone. Those who receive punishment as intended in this verse, in addition to being considered despicable in the world, are threatened with a great torment in the hereafter.
text.34: The disruptors of security and their punishments have been explained in verse 33 above. If they repent before being apprehended by the authorities, then the punishments mentioned in verse 33, which in Islamic law are called "hududullah," no longer apply to them. Furthermore, other punishments such as hadd, sariqah, and jinayah (criminal law) will not be carried out against them. This leniency given to those who repent is in accordance with the attributes of Allah, the Most Forgiving, the Most Merciful.
text.35:
Allah commands the believers to always be careful and self-aware, so as not to be involved in any transgression, committing religious prohibitions that Allah has commanded to avoid.

According to some mufassirun (Quran commentators), avoiding Allah's prohibitions is more difficult than obeying His commands. It is not surprising that in the Al-Qur'an, the word *ittaqu*, which means to guard ourselves from committing religious prohibitions, is mentioned repeatedly up to 69 times, while the word *ati'u*, which means to obey religious commands, is only mentioned 19 times.

In addition to guarding ourselves and tightening our defenses against things that might cause us to commit violations or religious stipulations, we must also always seek ways to draw closer to Allah, namely by carrying out His commands and practicing everything that pleases Him.

Ibn 'Abbas, Mujahid, Abu Wali, al-Hasan, Zaid, 'Ata, as-Sauri and others, interpret *al-wasilah* in this verse as drawing closer. Regarding this understanding, Ibn Kathir in his Tafsir (2/52), said:

The understanding that has been given by these imams is not subject to disagreement among the mufassirun.

The word *wasilah* sometimes means the highest place in Paradise, as the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) said:

"When you send blessings upon me, then ask for *wasilah* for me." Then he was asked: "O Messenger of Allah, what is *wasilah*?" The Messenger of Allah replied, " *Wasilah* is the highest degree in Paradise that no one will attain except one person, and I hope that I am that person." (Narrated by Ahmad from Abu Hurairah).

Avoiding and abandoning Allah's prohibitions and carrying out His commands are not easy things, because the desires that exist in every human being always invite them to do things that are contrary to what is good, namely violating and abandoning Allah's commands, as He says:

"Indeed, the soul is a persistent enjoiner of evil." (Yusuf /12:53).

Therefore, we must strive to restrain our desires, overcome all difficulties, and avoid all obstacles that will cause us to deviate from the path of Allah so that we are on the line that has been determined. Thus, we will obtain the happiness that Allah has promised.
text.36:
Those who do not want to be pious towards Allah and do not want to cleanse themselves of the sins they have committed, and remain in disbelief denying the divinity of Allah and worshiping other than Allah, and die without repenting, then on the Day of Judgment they will regret it. If everything on earth belonged to them, even with as much added again, and they wanted to free themselves from the torment that befalls them, then all of that would not be accepted by Him.

In a hadith, the Prophet Muhammad said:

A disbeliever will be brought on the Day of Judgment and it will be said to him, "If you possessed gold filling the entire earth, would you want to make it a ransom (for the punishment you will receive)?" He will answer, "Yes, I would." (Narrated by al-Bukhari from Anas r.a.).

But what can be done, the rice has become porridge (it's too late). Whatever their desire, it will not be accepted and they will still undergo punishment in the form of a very painful torment, because in the afterlife sin cannot be redeemed with material possessions. But if they repent during their lifetime and cleanse themselves with righteous deeds, then Allah will accept their repentance.
text.37:
After they are cast into Hell and can no longer bear the torment they suffer, they will want to escape, but there will be no way for them. Their situation is similar to what is mentioned in Allah's word:

"Every time they want to get out of it, they will be returned to it." (as-Sajdah/32:20).

They will feel eternal, everlasting torment that will never end.
text.38:
Every crime has its punishment. The perpetrator will be subjected to punishment. Similarly, a thief will be punished because he violates the prohibition against stealing. A person, whether male or female, who takes another person's property from its proper place secretly, is called a "thief."

A person who has reached puberty and steals another person's property worth at least a quarter of a dinar, willingly and not under duress, and knows that his action is haram, forbidden by religion, has met the conditions to be subjected to the punishment of cutting off the right hand, as commanded in this verse.

A theft can be established if there is evidence or a confession from the thief himself. The punishment of cutting off the hand can be waived if the thief is forgiven by the person whose property was stolen, provided this happens before the case is handled by the authorities. The implementation of the hand-cutting punishment is carried out by the authorized person appointed for that purpose, with certain conditions.

The determination of the value of the stolen property, for which the perpetrator is subject to the punishment of cutting off the hand, which is at least a quarter of a dinar as mentioned above, is the opinion of the majority of scholars (jumhur ulama), both salaf and khalaf, based on the saying of the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) as follows:

"The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) cut off the hand of a thief who stole a quarter of a dinar or more." (Narrated by al-Bukhari and Muslim from Aisyah).

A thief whose right hand has been cut off, and then steals again with the same conditions as before, then his left foot is cut off, from the tip of the foot to the ankle. If he steals again for the third time, his left hand is cut off again. If he steals again for the fourth time, his right foot is cut off again, as in the saying of the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) regarding thieves as follows:

"If he steals, cut off his (right) hand. If he steals again, cut off his (left) foot. If he steals again, cut off his (left) hand. And if he still steals, cut off his (right) foot." (Narrated by al-Imam al-Syafi'i from Abu Hurairah).

If all of this has been implemented but he still steals for the fifth time, then he is given ta'zir, meaning he is given punishment according to what is determined by the ruler, for example, imprisoned or exiled to another place, so that he can no longer steal. Cutting off the hand is commanded by Allah as a punishment for thieves, both male and female, because Allah is the All-Powerful, so He will not allow thieves and other people to commit disobedience. Allah is All-Wise in determining something, such as establishing the law of cutting off the hand for thieves, because if this is considered more deeply, its implementation will certainly bring many benefits, at least it can limit the rampant theft.

Whatever Allah commands will surely bring benefit, and whatever He forbids will surely result in damage and destruction if violated.
text.39:
In the time of the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him), a woman stole. This was reported to the Prophet (peace be upon him) by the people who were stolen from. They said, "This is the woman who stole our belongings; her tribe will ransom her." The Prophet (peace be upon him) said, "Cut off her hand." Her tribe explained: "We are willing to ransom her for five hundred dinars." The Prophet (peace be upon him) said, "Cut off her hand." So the woman's right hand was cut off. Then she asked, "Is my repentance still accepted, O Messenger of Allah?" He replied, "Yes, today you are as free from your sins as the day you were born by your mother." Then this verse was revealed.

The woman was from the tribe of Bani Makhzum, who received great attention from the leaders of the Quraysh. Initially, they tried to free the woman from the punishment of having her hand cut off. Then they looked for someone who could contact the Messenger of Allah to discuss the matter. Then Usamah bin Zaid was appointed because he was a favorite of the Messenger of Allah. When Usamah bin Zaid visited the Messenger of Allah and discussed the matter, the Messenger of Allah became angry and said, "Are you interceding concerning one of the legal punishments prescribed by Allah 'azza wa jalla?" Usamah replied, "Forgive me, O Messenger of Allah." After that, the Messenger of Allah gave a speech, among other things, he said,

"Verily, what destroyed the people before you was that if the one who stole among them was a person of high status, they would let him go, but if the one who stole was a weak person, they would inflict the punishment upon him. By Allah, in Whose Hand is my soul, if Fatimah, the daughter of Muhammad, were to steal, I would surely cut off her hand." Then he ordered that the woman's hand be cut off, and so her hand was cut off. (Narrated by asy-Syaikhan from 'Aisyah).

So whoever repents from his actions and promises not to steal again, after he has wronged himself and tarnished his reputation, and defiled the sanctity of his people, by returning what he stole, then he is forgiven by Allah because Allah is Most Forgiving to those who repent. He is Most Merciful to those who are humble and like to admit their mistakes.
text.40: This verse warns and emphasizes that Allah is the One who controls the heavens and the earth, regulating what is within them. Allah is the One who decrees the punishment for those who steal, just as He punishes those who wage war against Allah and His Messenger, yet He forgives those who repent among them, showing mercy to those who sincerely repent, improve their deeds, and purify themselves from the sins they have committed. Allah will punish those who violate His commands as an education and safeguard for fellow humans, just as Allah has mercy on those who repent, encouraging them to purify themselves. Allah is All-Powerful over all things; such as punishing and showing mercy. Nothing is difficult for Him in regulating everything, according to His will.
text.41:
In this verse, Allah commands His Messenger not to feel sad and anxious because of the actions of the hypocrites who display their disbelief and show their hostility, because in due time Allah will protect him from their evil deeds and grant him victory over them and all their helpers and supporters. Among them are those who claim to believe with their words, but their hearts remain in denial and do not believe; similarly, some of the Jews.

They are very happy to hear the words of scholars and priests, as well as those who hate the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) and have never met him, especially listening to lectures and false news that has been fabricated to denigrate Muhammad (peace be upon him) and weaken the spirit of the Muslims so that they abandon his teachings.

They do not hesitate to change the contents of the Torah. They move its sentences around, so that what should be in front is placed behind, and vice versa. Its meaning is distorted and so on; for example, replacing the punishment of stoning for adulterers with flogging and blackening the face. They said to their own envoy who was assigned to go to Bani Quraizah to ask them to ask the Prophet (peace be upon him) about the punishment for two leaders who had committed adultery and had been married. They advised as follows, "If Muhammad answers that the punishment is flogging and blackening the face, then accept and take that fatwa. But if he answers with something other than that, and affirms that the punishment is stoning, then avoid him and do not accept it." Those whom Allah wills to be in error because of their excessive actions, then there is no guidance that they can receive even if the guidance comes from the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him).

Allah will not purify the hearts of the hypocrites and the Jews because they hold fast and do not want to budge even a little from their disbelief and error. In this world, the hypocrites obtain humiliation and feel very ashamed because their hypocrisy is revealed and known to the Muslims, while the Jews also obtain humiliation because their evil deeds can be known. Likewise, their actions of concealing the contents of the Torah, for example, the punishment of stoning. In addition to all of that, in the Hereafter they will also receive a great punishment. They will be punished continuously, without end, and will not be taken out of hell for all time.
text.42:
This verse once again explains the characteristics of the Jews who are fond of listening to false news about the person and prophethood of Prophet Muhammad, peace be upon him, to show that the actions of the Jews are always based on untrue and false things; a very ugly, despicable, and destructive trait.

In addition to that, they also receive a lot of bribes, which is a gift with the intention of justifying what is wrong or blaming what is right. This has become one of their livelihoods, especially for the rulers. The law is manipulated, and what plays a role and determines things at that time is bribery. Whoever is strong in giving bribes, he will win the case, even if he is clearly guilty.

If among the Jews there is someone who is displeased and does not agree with the dirty deeds of his superiors, and then he comes to Prophet Muhammad and asks for his case to be decided; the Messenger is free to choose, to accept their request and decide the case, or to reject it. They will not be able to harm the Messenger in the slightest if the Messenger rejects it.

If the Messenger accepts their request, then the Messenger must decide their case as fairly as possible in accordance with what has been commanded, in line with the sharia that was brought, and not contrary to the Al-Qur'an. Allah is pleased and content with those who act justly.
text.43:
One thing that is astonishing about them is that they call and invite their people to believe in the Torah, but they are unwilling to submit to its contents and laws, even though the Torah contains God's laws that are quite clear. They even seek legal rulings from other people.

Because they are not believers, it is all the same to them. They abandon and refuse to submit to the Torah, because its contents and laws do not align with their desires and the whims of their passions. Likewise, if a matter or issue is decided based on the Al-Qur'an according to their request, they will also abandon that decision and ignore it if the decision contradicts their desires and passions.
text.44:
The Torah, which Allah revealed to Prophet Musa, contains guidance and direction for mankind towards the truth, so that they can escape and be saved from misguidance and idol worship. It is also a light that illuminates things that are still vague or dark for them, so that they can see the right path, both in religious and worldly matters.

The Torah became a guide for the prophets who had surrendered themselves to Allah with complete sincerity, namely Prophet Musa and the prophets from the Children of Israel after him, up to Prophet Isa. This book was used to decide cases only for the Jews, because the Torah was indeed revealed specifically for the Jews. Likewise, their leaders and priests used the Torah as law when there was no prophet with them, because they were all commanded by Allah to preserve the Torah, and to be witnesses and responsible for its implementation. They should not distort the laws contained therein, and hide them because they contradict their desires, or because they fear their superiors so they do not dare to enforce the law against them, as if they fear fellow humans more than Allah. This is different from Abdullah bin Salam who lived until the time of al-Khulafa ar-Rasyidun. He was a Jew who truly upheld the law of Allah, which caused others to hate and dislike him. He enforced the law of stoning against anyone who should be punished for adultery, even against their leaders or superiors.

They should not fail to disseminate and explain these laws for worldly gain or benefits received from interested parties, such as bribes, or ranks promised to them, because all of this has no meaning or value when compared to the reward they will receive in the Hereafter. Allah says:

"(It is) the Day when wealth or children will be of no avail, except for whoever brings to Allah a sound heart." (asy-Syu'ara/26: 88 and 89).

Whoever judges or decides a matter not in accordance with the law of Allah, as was the case with the Jews who hid the law of stoning for adulterers who were married and replaced it with the punishment of flogging and blackening their faces, then parading them around to be witnessed by the community, and so on, means they are distorting the law. Know that they are the disbelievers.
text.45:
In the Torah, it has been established that a life must be paid for with a life. A person who kills without a just reason must also be killed, regardless of who the killer is and who is killed. (Exodus xxi. 24-25: "must give life for life, eye for eye, tooth for tooth, hand for hand, foot for foot, burn for burn, wound for wound, bruise for bruise..."). Similar punishments are also found in Leviticus xxiv and Deuteronomy xix.21.

Even though these stipulations and provisions were known by Christians and Jews, they still refused to implement and execute them. They still considered there to be differences in degrees and strata within society. They considered the Jewish group of Bani Nadir to be of higher degree and status than the Jewish group of Bani Quraizah, and the group of Bani Quraizah to be of lower status compared to the group of Bani Nadir. So, if a member of the Bani Nadir killed a member of the Bani Quraizah, he would not be killed because he was not considered equal. But if the opposite happened, that is, a member of the Bani Quraizah killed a member of the Bani Nadir, then he would have to be killed.

This and similar things, which constituted disobedience and rejection of the guidance, instructions, and laws of Allah in the Torah, continued until the arrival of Islam. After that, the Bani Quraizah complained to the Prophet Muhammad about the class differences in their society. He decided that there was no difference between A and B, between the group of Anu and the group of Fulan, in the application of the law. The law is impartial; everyone must be treated equally. Upon hearing this decision of the Messenger of Allah (saw), the Bani Nadir felt that their status had been lowered because they had been equated with the Bani Quraizah, whom they considered inferior. Then this verse was revealed.

In this verse, Allah reaffirms that in the Torah, it has been outlined that a life must be paid for with a life, which is the same as the law of *qisas* that applies in Islamic law. A killer who has reached puberty (*akil balig*) who kills a fellow Muslim who is also free, then that killer, whether one person or several, must be subjected to the death penalty. Except for a madman whose mind is truly impaired, a person who is sleeping until he wakes up, and a child until he reaches puberty, if they kill, they are not subject to the *qisas* penalty, according to the Prophet's (saw) saying:

"The pen has been lifted from three types of people (meaning they are not treated as *mukallaf* people), namely, madmen whose minds have truly been impaired until they recover, people who are sleeping until they wake up, and children until they reach puberty." (Narrated by Ahmad, Abu Dawud from al-Hakim and 'Umar bin al-Khattab).

Furthermore, a person who gouges out an eye or cuts off the nose or ear or pulls out the teeth of another person is obligated to be subjected to the *qisas* penalty, acted upon according to his actions, in accordance with Allah's saying:

"Then whoever transgresses against you, you transgress likewise against him." (al-Baqarah/2:194).

Likewise, injuring someone has *qisas*. A person who injures another person must also be injured in the same way as the injury he inflicted, both in terms of width and depth, as Allah says:

"And if you punish [an oppressor], punish him with an equivalent of that with which you were harmed." (an-Nahl/16:126).

Whoever relinquishes his right to *qisas* willingly and forgives the perpetrator so that he is not subjected to *qisas*, it becomes an expiation of sins for the one who forgives. A person who is released from the *qisas* penalty because he is forgiven by the family of the person who was killed does not mean that he is completely free from punishment, but he is still subject to the *diat* (compensation) penalty, as the Prophet (saw) said:

From Abu 'Amr, the Messenger of Allah (saw) said, "Whoever kills intentionally, then the decision is left to the heirs of the person who was killed. If they want (to apply *qisas*), they can kill him, and if they want (to release him from *qisas*), then they are entitled to receive *diat* (compensation)." (Narrated by at-Tirmidhi).

Whoever does not implement the provisions above, namely, *qisas* based on justice, but rather uses the law according to his own desires, then they are the wrongdoers, because they violate Allah's law and consider the party that was killed or abused to be of a low class, not equal to the party that killed or abused.
text.46:
In this verse, it is explained that after the era of the prophets who adhered to and implemented the contents of the Torah ended, Prophet Isa, son of Maryam, was sent, following in the footsteps of the previous prophets of the Children of Israel, implementing the Torah that had been revealed before.

Then the Gospel (Injil) was revealed to Prophet Isa, perfecting the contents of the Torah whose validity had ended, adapted to the situation and conditions of his people and society. The Gospel contains guidance and is a light that illuminates his people, so that they can see the right path that brings them happiness. The Gospel confirms the previous heavenly book, namely the Torah, which contains values that can save its people from error in faith and deeds, such as *tauhid* eradicating *shirk* and idols which are the source of superstition and falsehood.
