The Gospel contains guidance and teachings, for example, the teaching that announces the coming of a prophet (New Testament, John xiv.16, xv. 26 and xvi.7. see also the *tafsir* on as-shaff/61:6), who has noble qualities, whose *sharia* is more perfect and universal, not limited by time and place. He is the final prophet and the last messenger. But none can benefit from all this guidance and teaching except those who are righteous (*muttaqin*).
text.47: In this verse, Allah clearly commands the followers of the Gospel, namely the adherents of the law of Prophet Isa, to implement the contents of the Gospel until the coming of the final prophet and messenger from the Arab nation, so that they judge according to what Allah has revealed in it, without distorting it or interpreting it according to their own desires, as was the case with the adherents of the law of Prophet Musa. Nevertheless, not a few of them were disobedient, distorting its meaning and understanding. They changed and adapted it to the wishes of their leaders, so that the original Gospel, which was truly divine, was no longer known to exist. They are the *fasik* (those who deviate from obedience to Allah) because they no longer judge and decide matters according to what Allah has revealed.
text.48:
After explaining that the Torah was revealed to Prophet Musa, and the Gospel was also revealed to Prophet Isa, and that both books should be obeyed and practiced by their respective followers. In this verse, it is explained that Allah revealed the Qur'an to the last Prophet and Messenger, Muhammad saw. The Qur'an is the last Heavenly Book that carries the truth, encompassing the content and confirming the previous Holy Books such as the Torah and the Gospel. The Qur'an is a well-preserved book, so it will not undergo changes or falsifications. Allah's word affirms:

"(Falsehood cannot approach it from before it or from behind it; [it is] sent down from a [Lord who is] Wise and Praiseworthy." (Fussilat/41:42).

The Qur'an is a holy book that guarantees the purity of the previous laws, and a holy book that is valid from its revelation until the Day of Judgment. Therefore, it is obligatory to judge and decide human affairs according to the law that Allah has revealed, which is contained in the Qur'an. It is not appropriate to follow the desires and lusts of those who contradict the truth brought by our leader, Prophet Muhammad saw.

Each people was given a sharia (specific regulations), and they were obliged to implement it, and they were also given a path and guidance that must be followed to cleanse themselves and purify their inner selves. The sharia of each people and the path to be taken may change and vary, but the foundation and basis of the heavenly religion is only one, namely tawhid (monotheism).

The Torah, the Gospel, and the Qur'an, each have their own sharia, which contains provisions of halal and haram laws, according to His will to know who is obedient and who is not. Allah's word:

"And We did not send any messenger before you (O Muhammad) except that We revealed to him that, "There is no deity except Me, so worship Me." (al-Anbiya'/21:25).

"And We certainly sent into every nation a messenger, [saying], "Worship Allah and avoid ṭāghūt." (an-Nahl/16:36).

If Allah had willed, He could have made all humans with only one sharia and one kind of path to be taken and practiced by them, so that from time to time there would be no increase or progress, like birds or bees, Allah's will would certainly be carried out and there would be no difficulty whatsoever, because Allah is All-Powerful over everything. But that is not what He wanted. Allah wants humans to be creatures who can use their minds and thoughts, can advance and develop from time to time. From childhood to adolescence, progressing to adulthood and so on.

Thus, Allah wills and gives each people a separate sharia, to test to what extent humans can and are able to carry out Allah's commands or avoid His prohibitions, as has been stipulated in His heavenly book, to be rewarded or punished. Therefore, humans should compete in doing good deeds and righteous deeds, according to the sharia brought by the final prophet, the last messenger, Muhammad saw. A sharia that replaces the previous sharia, for the benefit of the world and happiness in the hereafter.

At some point in the future, inevitably, humans will return to Allah to fulfill His call to the eternal realm. There, Allah will inform them of everything about the truth that they disputed. Those who truly believe will be rewarded, while those who deny and reject the truth, and deviate without reason or evidence, will be punished and thrown into hell.
text.49:
It is narrated by Ibn Jarir and al-Baihaqi from Ibn Abbas, that Kaab bin Asad, Abdullah bin Suriya, Wisyas bin Qais from the Jews said, "Let us go to Muhammad, perhaps we can mislead him." So they went to the Messenger of Allah and said to the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him:

"O Muhammad, you know that we are the Jewish priests, the dignitaries and leaders. If we follow you, the Jews will surely follow us and none of them will dare to oppose. There is a dispute between us and our people. We will bring that dispute to you, so you should favor us against them, and we will believe and affirm you." But the Messenger of Allah refused (to follow their wishes) and Allah Azza wa Jalla revealed a verse about their affair.... *wa anihkum bainahum bima anzala Allah....* (Narrated by Ibn Jarir and al-Baihaqi from Ibn Abbas)

The Prophet, peace be upon him, rejected their request, so this verse was revealed. The Prophet Muhammad was instructed to judge the affairs of the Jews that were submitted to him in accordance with what Allah had revealed and never to follow their desires and whims. Allah reminded the Prophet to be careful in dealing with their tactics, lest he be trapped by their deception, which sought to divert him from some of the laws that Allah had revealed and prescribed to him.

If they still turn away and refuse to accept a decision based on what Allah has revealed, because their intention in asking the Prophet to decide their case is merely to provoke and trap him, in the hope that he might deviate from the law of Allah. Know that this is because Allah intends to inflict punishment upon them in this world, as a result of their sins, and it will be completed later in the Hereafter, a most painful torment. Indeed, most people are *fasik* (rebellious), behaving like the disbelievers, happy to abandon the laws of Allah and the *sharia* that has been chosen for them.
text.50:
It is narrated that the Banu Nadir brought a case that occurred with the Banu Qurayza to the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) to be judged. Some of the Banu Nadir asked the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) to decide the case according to the decisions that were in effect during the time of ignorance (jahiliyyah), namely the existence of differences in status between the two groups, so that the *diyat* (blood money) imposed on the Banu Qurayza would be twice the *diyat* imposed on the Banu Nadir, because according to them, the Banu Nadir were stronger, more noble, and of higher status. The Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) did not accept their request and he said, "Those who are killed are of equal status, there is no difference." The people of Banu Nadir said, "If that is the case, then we also reject and do not accept that." Then this verse was revealed.

In this verse, Allah mocks and considers their actions as something strange. They possess a heavenly book and extensive knowledge, but they still prioritize the laws of *jahiliyyah* which clearly contradict the laws in the Torah, even though the laws of Allah are the best laws, because they are comprehensive, just, and true, without regard to status or anything else.
text.51:
This verse prohibits believers from taking Jews and Christians as close friends who will provide assistance and protection, let alone trusting them as leaders. Besides this verse, there are many other verses in the Qur'an that state similar prohibitions against Jews and Christians. The repeated emphasis of this prohibition in several verses of the Qur'an indicates that the issue is very important and that violating it will bring great danger.

This prohibition applies to individuals. A believer is forbidden from making Jews and Christians close friends, a place to confide secrets and trust, as with fellow believers. Likewise, it applies to the community and society of believers, that they are forbidden to make Jews and Christians their defenders, protectors, and helpers, especially in matters related to religion. If it is only for ordinary friendship in social interaction, especially in worldly affairs, Allah does not forbid it, as long as one is careful in association, because for them, breaking promises and lying to seek worldly gain is commonplace. This was demonstrated by the Messenger of Allah when he was in Medina. He established working relationships with Jews and Christians and sometimes made defense agreements with them, if it was deemed beneficial for the believers.

Jews and Christians have a very strong sense of group and tribalism. Therefore, no matter how good their relationship with believers is, even to the point of making agreements to cooperate with them, if it will harm their group and nation, they will not hesitate to turn back, betray their promises, and become enemies of the believers. They always help each other, united in facing the believers. Their outward appearance is good, but inwardly they are always looking for opportunities to destroy the believers.

The end of this verse affirms that whoever among the believers takes Jews and Christians as close friends, then that person belongs to their group, unconsciously, sooner or later that person will be influenced, not to help Islam, but to become an enemy of Islam. If he has become an enemy of Islam, it means he has wronged himself. Know that Allah will not guide those who do wrong to the right path to achieve a happy life in this world and the hereafter.
text.52: This verse explains to Muhammad that the Prophet will see those in whose hearts is a disease, namely the hypocrites who are weak in faith, not yet reaching the level of certainty, such as Abdullah bin Ubay and others. They are closer to the Jews than to the believers themselves. Abdullah bin Ubay, as the leader of the hypocrites, had closer daily relations with the Jews. Meanwhile, other hypocrites had dared to make cooperation agreements, even having closer cooperative relationships with the Jews. It was as if they were relying on the Jews for their safety, due to fear that if the Jews became strong and powerful, they themselves would be in danger. These hypocrites lacked faith in the strength of the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) and the Muslims, who would be helped by Allah with victory and glory. Allah has promised that every believer who strives to defend His religion will be helped with strength and victory. Then, at that time, regret will arise from those who doubt and are hypocritical, and the secrets of their hearts that they have kept hidden will be revealed.
text.53: This verse explains the state of the believers who have been given help and pleasure by Allah against their enemies, thanks to the strength of their faith and their unwavering determination. Some of them, with feelings of wonder and astonishment, said to others about the state of the hypocrites who had regretted and revealed their secrets, because they had placed their hopes on the Jews and Christians to defend and help them. Suddenly, their hopes were in vain, even though the hypocrites had sworn allegiance to join the believers in destroying the Jews. That oath of allegiance was nothing but a false deception, yet they had made a cooperation agreement with the Jews. The consequence of their hypocrisy did not benefit them, but instead made them humiliated in front of people and cursed before Allah. Thus, their deeds were erased, and they received no reward from Allah, even though they always performed *salat*, fasted, and participated in *jihad* alongside the believers, because of their hypocrisy. In fact, they are included among those who are at a loss in this world and the hereafter.
text.54:
In this verse is contained the news of a challenge that will occur, namely the apostasy of some believers. They will openly leave Islam. Their departure from Islam will not harm the believers, but on the contrary, Allah will replace them with people who are stronger in faith and better in their deeds, as replacements for those who apostatized.

According to a narration from Ibn Jarir from Qatadah, it is narrated that after this verse was revealed, several groups of people would apostatize, leaving the religion of Islam. This event then truly happened when the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) passed away, some Muslims apostatized, except for those from three places: the inhabitants of Medina, the inhabitants of Mecca, and the inhabitants of Bahrain. Among the signs of their apostasy was that they no longer wanted to pay zakat. They said: "We will continue to pray, but we do not want to pay zakat. By Allah, our wealth must not be seized." So, the Caliph Abu Bakr at that time was forced to take firm action. Those who apostatized were fought, so that some of them died, some were burned, and some were captured, and finally they were willing to pay zakat again.

The events of this apostasy are numerous. History mentions that during the lifetime of the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him), there were three instances of apostasy:

1.  The group of Bani Madzhij, led by Zulkhimar, namely al-Aswad al-Ansi, a sorcerer. He claimed to be a prophet in Yemen, and he was killed by one of the Muslims.

2.  The group of Bani Hanifah, namely Musailimah al-Kadzdzab. Musailimah claimed to be a prophet. He once sent a letter to the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) inviting him to divide the power in the Arab lands in two. He would rule half the country and the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) would rule the rest. The Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) replied to his letter by saying that the earth belongs to Allah and Allah will bequeath this earth to whomever He wills among His servants and that the final victory will be for those who are pious to Him. Finally, Musailimah was fought by Caliph Abu Bakr and he was killed by Wahsyi, who had previously killed Hamzah, the Prophet's uncle, in the Battle of Uhud.

3.  The group of Bani Asad, whose leader was named Thulaihah bin Khuwailid. He also claimed to be a prophet, so Abu Bakr fought him by ordering Khalid bin Walid to kill him. He retreated and fled to the land of Syria and eventually he returned to being a good Muslim.

After the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) died, during the time of Caliph Abu Bakr, many groups apostatized, consisting of 7 groups, namely: (1) Gatafan, (2) Khuza'ah, (3) Bani Sulaim, (4) Bani Yarbu', (5) some of Bani Tamim, (6) Kindah, and (7) Bani Bakr.

The people who replaced those who apostatized always spoke the truth and helped the struggle of Islam, marked by Allah with six important characteristics, namely:

1.  Allah loves them, because of their faith and conviction in struggling.

2.  They love Allah, because Allah's commands are given priority over other matters.

3.  They are gentle towards the believers.

4.  They are stern and firm towards the disbelievers.

5.  *Berjihad fi sabilillah*, which is to strive earnestly in upholding the religion of Allah, willing to sacrifice with their wealth and themselves and not afraid to fight the enemies of religion.

6.  They are not afraid of insults and reproaches, not afraid of threats and intimidation. Because in their deeds and struggles, they are not seeking praise and flattery from people, nor are they seeking rank and position, nor are they seeking name and influence. What they seek is only the pleasure of Allah alone.

The characteristics mentioned above are a favor from Allah to His servants whom He wills. With these characteristics, a person's degree becomes high and noble in the eyes of humans, and especially in the eyes of Allah, who has great bounty. All of that can be obtained by drawing closer to Allah and increasing worship and gratitude.
text.55:
In this verse, Allah reaffirms the issue of *wali*, which is that the helper and protector of believers is none other than Allah, His Messenger, and the believers themselves. This affirmation is intended to prevent believers from doubting and being weak in their stance, due to the whispers and enticements of those with weak faith. They should be steadfast, confident in their struggle, not relying on others except fellow believers, and not seeking help except from Allah alone.

This verse explains the characteristics of believers who will be made leaders and helpers. Not just anyone can claim to be a believer, because many people only claim to be believers with their mouths, but in their daily actions, they display the actions of hypocrites. Sometimes they participate in worship, such as performing *salat*, fasting, and so on, but only to attract the attention of believers, merely pretending, not coming from the depths of their hearts. Their actions are often driven by *riya* (showing off), wanting to be praised and seen by others; they rarely remember and submit to Allah's commands. One must be careful in dealing with such people, especially in making them leaders and helpers.

There are three kinds of actions and deeds that must be possessed by a believer who will be made a leader and helper, namely:

1.  Establishing *salat*, in the true sense. Performed according to its time and according to the prescribed manners. So that the *salat* can influence words and deeds, making him a believer who is moral, trustworthy, and can be followed.

2.  Paying *zakat* to those who are entitled to receive it, with full obedience and submission to Allah. By paying *zakat*, he becomes a kind-hearted, generous person, who cares about the fate of his followers and his people. From him come good examples in defending believers, especially weak and poor believers.

3.  Humbling oneself to Allah. Towards Allah, he continues to worship, and towards society, he displays noble morals and actions.
text.56: This verse is Allah's guarantee to the believers who have made Allah, His Messenger, and the believers their leaders and helpers. Allah guarantees and promises them victory. They are called "hizbullah," the loyal followers of Allah's religion. Allah's help will descend upon them, so that they will achieve the most glorious victory.
text.57:
From this verse and the following verses, we can also understand the reasons for the prohibition against taking the disbelievers as protectors and helpers.

According to the narration of Ibn Ishaq and a group from Ibn Abbas, it is narrated that Rifa'ah bin Zaid bin Attabut and Suwaid Ibnu Haris, both of whom were hypocrites who declared themselves to be Muslims, so many Muslims became close friends with them, and then this verse was revealed.

This verse forbids believers from taking disbelievers who mock and make fun of the Islamic religion as loyal friends, protectors, and helpers, whether they are original disbelievers, fire worshippers, idolaters, etc., or those who are not original, such as the People of the Book, namely the Jews and Christians.

Some commentators explain, among other things, as follows: Islam distinguishes between the People of the Book and the polytheistic disbelievers of Arabia, namely by allowing the eating of animals slaughtered by the People of the Book and marrying their women with certain conditions as mentioned in Surah al-Ma'idah/5:5, and forbidding arguing with those who are unjust, as explained in Surah al-'Ankabut. In this verse, the term "People of the Book" refers to those who adhere to Judaism and Christianity, even though the Torah and the Gospel, which are their holy books, have been mixed with human words and they do not believe in the Qur'an.221) As for the term Mushrik or Mushrikin, it is for the original disbelievers, because they have associated partners with Allah from the beginning, while the element of associating partners with Allah found in the core of the beliefs of the People of the Book came later, not from their original teachings.

Furthermore, Allah commands the believers to be pious and avoid His prohibitions, namely to be close friends with disbelievers, whether original disbelievers or disbelievers from the People of the Book, because there is no longer any reason for those who truly believe to be close friends or help each other with disbelievers who mock and make fun of other religions.
text.58:
This verse explains some of the mockery and games of the disbelievers towards the Islamic religion, namely, when Muslims invite them to prayer, the disbelievers make that invitation a subject of ridicule and play while laughing at them.

According to a narration by Ibn Jarir from as-Suddi, he narrated that there was a Christian man in Medina who, when he heard the call to prayer, *Asyhadu anna Muhammad Rasulullah* (I bear witness that Muhammad is the Messenger of Allah), he would say, "*haraqa al-Kadzdzab*" (may the liar be burned). Then one night, his maidservant came in carrying fire, and a small spark from the fire she was carrying fell, causing the entire house to burn down, and the Christian man and his family were burned to death while they were sleeping.

Furthermore, it is explained that the actions of the disbelievers are due to the fact that they are a people who do not want to use their intellect and do not want to know about the essence of God's religion, which obligates them to glorify and worship Him.

If they used their intellect reasonably, without being influenced by hatred and animosity, then their hearts would be humble when they heard the *adhan* with a melodious voice, especially if they understood and comprehended the *adhan* which begins with words that glorify Allah.
text.59:
According to a narration, Ibn Jarir and others relate that some Jews, including Abu Yasir bin Akhtab and others, asked the Prophet Muhammad about which messengers he believed in. The Prophet Muhammad replied, "I believe in Allah and what has been revealed to us and what was revealed to Ibrahim, Ishak, Yakub and Asbat, and what Allah gave to Musa, Isa and the other prophets, without making any distinction between them. And we submit to Him." When the Prophet Muhammad mentioned Isa, they did not acknowledge his prophethood, saying, "We do not believe in those who believe in him," so this verse was revealed.

This verse guides the Prophet Muhammad saw to refute the People of the Book with a question, "O People of the Book, do you consider us wrong, hate us, and insult us, only because we believe in Allah and in what was revealed to His messengers of old? We do nothing other than that, because there is no reason for you to blame and hate us, except that most of you have indeed become transgressors ( *fasik* )."

In essence, they could not answer this rebuttal except by being indifferent and continuing to mock and insult Islam and the Muslims. Therefore, Allah revealed the following verse to provide a stronger rebuttal, so that they would all be silent.
text.60:
This verse is part of Allah's guidance to His Messenger Muhammad to provide a rebuttal to the People of the Book, as outlined in verse 59.

According to a narration from At-Tabarani, he recounts that the People of the Book said to the Prophet Muhammad, meaning, "We know of no religion worse than yours," so this verse was revealed to refute them.

In this verse, Allah commands the Prophet Muhammad to say the following: "Shall I inform you of something worse in recompense with Allah than [the example of] those who mock our religion and our call to prayer, namely, that you were made into apes and pigs?"

A narration from Ibn Abbas relates that the event of violating the sanctity of the Sabbath (Saturday) resulted in two kinds of occurrences. The first occurrence was that the young people were transformed into apes; the second, the old people became pigs. (See also Tafsir on 2:65 and 7:166) Furthermore, Allah commands His Messenger to convey that these are the ones who are worse in place in the Hereafter and further astray from the right path.
text.61:
After several verses explained the behavior of the disbelievers and the People of the Book from among the Jews, in this verse and the following few verses, Allah also explains the behavior of the hypocrites from the Jewish community of Medina and its surroundings.

According to the narration of Qatadah and as-Suddi, they narrated that the Jews came and declared their Islam to the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) and his companions who happened to be present at that time. Thus, this verse was revealed to expose the falsehood of these hypocrites.

This verse explains to Muhammad (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) and his companions, meaning: When the hypocrites from the Jews come to you saying, "We believe in the Messenger of Allah, Muhammad, and what has been revealed to him," then know that in their hearts, disbelief and error remain deeply rooted, unchanging from the time they enter your presence until they leave. Allah knows what they conceal in their hearts, while they visit you with deceitful schemes until they leave in all sorts of deceptive forms to learn about your situation, which they need to convey to their people.
text.62:
This verse also explains something that means the following: "And you, O Muhammad, will see many among the Jews taking your religion as a mockery and a game. They quickly continue and persist in sinful deeds and hostility, with words, such as mocking, insulting, lying, and so on. In addition, they constantly consume what is forbidden, such as usury (riba), bribes, corruption, and so on."

Furthermore, Allah says, meaning: "Indeed, how evil is what they have been doing," because in reality they have immersed themselves in a boundless ocean of evil, so that they can no longer be helped.
text.63:
This verse expresses reproach, the meaning of which is as follows: Why do the scholars and priests of the Jews not forbid their people from lying and consuming unlawful wealth?

Ibn Abbas narrated that there is no reproach in the Qur'an more severe than this verse against the scholars who neglect their duty in conveying da'wah about prohibitions and evils. The scholars of tafsir say that this verse is not merely narrating Allah's rebuke to the Jewish priests who did not guide the Jews who committed wickedness to the right path, but more importantly, what we must realize is that the Jews forbid Islamic scholars from conveying da'wah, especially encouraging good deeds and preventing evil deeds.
text.64:
According to the narration of Ibn Ishaq and at-Tabrani from Ibn Abbas, he said, "A Jew named Nabbash bin Qais said to the Prophet Muhammad, 'Your God is stingy, He doesn't like to give.'" So this verse, even though only one person from among the Jews said it to the Prophet, can be considered to depict the overall stance of their people. This verse narrates that the Jew said, "Allah's hand is tied," but in reality, it is their own hands that are tied, and thus they will be cursed by Allah.

The Jew's statement that "Allah's hand is tied" is illogical, because they acknowledge that Allah is the name for the Being who certainly exists and is All-Powerful, the Creator of the universe. This shows that Allah's hand is not tied, His power is limitless, because if it were, He would not be able to maintain and regulate this universe. So what prompted them to utter such words? Some commentators suggest the following motivations:

1. Perhaps they heard the verse:

Whoever lends to Allah a good loan - then He will multiply it for him many times. And it is Allah who withholds and grants abundance, and to Him you will be returned. (al-Baqarah/2:245).

After hearing this verse, they said that Allah's hand is tied, meaning stingy, because Allah is incapable and poor, so He needs a loan.

2. They uttered these words to mock the Muslims when they saw the Prophet's companions in hardship and financial difficulty.

3. Initially, the Jewish community was wealthy. When the Prophet Muhammad was sent as a Messenger, they opposed him, therefore they spent a lot of wealth to finance the effort to thwart his da'wah, so many wealthy people among them became poor. Because Allah no longer expanded the sustenance for those who had become poor, they uttered the words "Allah's hand is tied," meaning Allah is stingy because He does not help them.

The statement in this verse states that "It is the hands of the Jews that are tied, and they receive a curse because of what they have said," is a statement about their stinginess, that is, they are the ones who are stingy, their hands are tied, they do not want to give assistance. Indeed, they are a stingy people, they are only willing to give assistance if they see a hope of obtaining a large profit. And they will certainly receive Allah's curse on the Day of Judgment as a reward for their actions.

This verse also affirms that Allah is Most Generous and He gives as He wills. The word "hand" in Arabic has several meanings, namely: (1) one of the human body parts, (2) strength, (3) possession (ownership), and (4) the blessing of grace.

It is the fourth meaning that is intended by the word "hand" attributed to Allah in this verse. This is how the later scholars (khalaf) interpret the hand in this verse. Thus, the phrase "both of Allah's hands are open" should be interpreted as the blessing of Allah's grace is widespread, that blessing of grace is given to whomever He wills. As for those who do not receive the blessing of Allah's grace, they should not think that Allah is stingy or poor.

The difference in levels of people in receiving sustenance from Allah is part of *sunnatullah*. Allah says:

"Is it they who would apportion the mercy of your Lord? It is We who have apportioned among them their livelihood in the life of this world and have raised some of them above others in degrees [of rank] that they may make use of one another for service. But the mercy of your Lord is better than what they accumulate." (az-Zukhruf/43:32).

The commentators in interpreting this verse have two opinions, namely:

First, known as the experts in *ta'wil*, which is to interpret the meaning of words according to the *majazi* (figurative) meaning, for example the verse:

"But the Face of your Lord will endure, Owner of Majesty and Honor." (ar-Rahman/55:27).

This group interprets the word "face", for example in the sentence "I did not see the face of so-and-so" the meaning is the self or essence of so-and-so. So that sentence is the same as the sentence "I did not see so-and-so" (without mentioning the word "face").

Second, the group of *tafwid* experts, which is to surrender the meaning of such sentences or words to Allah. They interpret the hand with its literal meaning. So this interprets the word "face" in the verse of Surah ar-Rahman according to its literal meaning, namely "face." As for what the state of God's face is like, they also surrender it to God, and in this case they adhere to the verse:

"There is nothing like unto Him" (asy-Syura/42:11).

So this group establishes that God has a face, but not like the face of a human being.

This verse states to Muhammad that what was revealed to him will truly increase the wickedness and disbelief for most of the Jews and explains that the verse that was revealed contains knowledge that was not known by the Jews who lived at the time of the Prophet Muhammad. Because if that were not the case, Muhammad would not know all of that, because he was *ummi*, unable to read or write. But because of envy and fanaticism, the Jews are increasingly far from believing in the Prophet Muhammad, even though the prophethood of Muhammad has been written in the holy book.

This verse also explains that Allah will create enmity among the People of the Book. That enmity will not end until the Day of Judgment. The character of the Jews is indeed fond of igniting the fire of war, slander and chaos. Such a character has been recorded in history and proves that they always try to deceive the Prophet Muhammad and the believers, both directly and by persuading the polytheists or Christians to fight the Prophet Muhammad and the believers.

Such a character leads them to enjoy doing and seeing destruction on earth. But every time they ignite the fire of war, slander and chaos, and try to create destruction, Allah still extinguishes it, because Allah does not like those who do damage, therefore their efforts to create damage and disaster on this earth always fail.
text.65: This verse explains that if the People of the Book were to believe in Allah and believe in Muhammad (peace be upon him) as the final Prophet, and they were to be pious by avoiding sinful deeds, then Allah would surely forgive all the sins and evil deeds they had committed. Allah would admit them into Paradise, which is filled with all kinds of blessings. This forgiveness from Allah and the promised Paradise are dependent on faith, piety, and obedience. Faith without piety is hypocrisy, used only to seek worldly gains. According to this verse, Allah is the Most Forgiving and forgives the sins of those who believe and are pious.
text.66:
This verse explains that if the People of the Book truly uphold the laws of the Torah and the Gospel, such as believing in the oneness of God and adhering to the good news found in the Torah and the Gospel about the prophethood of Muhammad, then Allah would certainly ease their lives. So, if in the previous verse Allah promised the People of the Book happiness in the Hereafter if they believe and are righteous, they will receive worldly happiness, abundant sustenance, and an outpouring of His mercy from the heavens, by causing various plants to grow. Despite this, they remain disobedient and oppose the messengers of Allah.

This verse also explains that among the Jews, there is a group that is hesitant in their religion, not adhering fanatically to the opinions of their priests, nor taking them lightly. Indeed, the majority of the Jews are very fanatical about the opinions of their priests. It is this group whose behavior is bad. A similar thing happens among the Christians.

According to custom, although the moderate group from each religion does not have many followers, from among them arise people who like to improve the situation, follow developments, and accept the truth. Such people are found in every community and in every era. For example, Abdullah bin Salam and his companions from among the Jews became loyal followers of the Prophet Muhammad. Likewise, Najashi and his companions from among the Christians also became loyal followers of the Prophet Muhammad. This shows that the function of religious adherents is to seek the truth. So, if an adherent of a religion adheres to the guidance of the religion correctly, then he will certainly not become fanatical, rigid, and accept the religion that is justified in his books. In seeking the truth, the main capital is sincerity accompanied by knowledge. Seeking the truth with this capital is found in Islam. Muslims themselves who do not practice the guidance of Islam will certainly not be able to obtain the truth that exists in Islam. In connection with this verse, there is a hadith of the Prophet narrated by Ziad bin Labid, namely:

From Ziad bin Labid, he said, "The Prophet Muhammad, peace be upon him, discussed something and then he said, "This will happen when knowledge has disappeared." Ziad said, "We (the companions) said, "O Messenger of Allah, how can knowledge disappear, while we read the Qur'an and we recite it to our children, and our children recite it to their children until the Day of Judgment." The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, replied, "Woe to you, O son of Ibn Labid, if I knew that you were the most knowledgeable people among the inhabitants of Medina, do not the Jews and Christians read the Torah and the Gospel, while they do not benefit from it at all?" (Narrated by Ahmad).

It is clear from this hadith that Muslims who do not practice the guidance of their religion are similar to the Jews and Christians. According to the narration of Ibn Abi Hatim, after that conversation, this verse 66 was revealed.
text.67:
This verse commands the Prophet Muhammad to convey what has been revealed to him without regard to the magnitude of the challenges from the People of the Book, the polytheists, and the wicked.

This verse encourages the Prophet Muhammad not to fear facing interference from them in exposing their secrets and the ugliness of their behavior, because Allah guarantees to protect the Prophet Muhammad from interference, both in the period before the Hijrah by the Quraish infidels and after the Hijrah by the Jews. What Allah has revealed to Muhammad is a trust that must be conveyed in its entirety to mankind. Conveying only a portion of His trust is considered the same as not conveying it at all. Such is the severity of Allah's warning to Muhammad. This shows that the task of conveying the trust is the duty of the Messenger. This task of conveyance should not be delayed, even if the delay is to wait for people's ability to accept it, because the period of delay can be considered an act of concealing Allah's trust.

The threat against concealing a portion of Allah's trust is as severe as the threat against someone who believes in only some of the messengers and believes in only some of the verses of the Qur'an. Although a messenger is *maksum*, that is, protected from the characteristic of not conveying, this verse affirms that the task of conveying the trust is an obligation that cannot be bargained or delayed, even if it concerns the Messenger himself, as later happened between Zainab binti Jahsy and the Prophet Muhammad, as described in al-Ahzab/33:37:

"And [remember, O Muhammad], when you said to the one on whom Allah bestowed favor and you bestowed favor, "Keep your wife and fear Allah," while you concealed within yourself that which Allah is to disclose. And you feared the people, while Allah has more right that you fear Him. (al-Ahzab/33:37).

In this regard, Aisha and Anas said, "If the Prophet Muhammad were to conceal something in the Qur'an, this verse would certainly be the one he concealed." From the statements of 'Aisha and Anas, it is clear that the event that later occurred between Zainab binti Jahsy and Zaid was a divorce that continued with the enactment of Allah's will, namely marrying Zainab to the Prophet Muhammad. This was not conveyed by the Prophet Muhammad to Zaid when he complained about the incident to the Prophet Muhammad, even though he already knew about it through revelation. The Prophet Muhammad, peace be upon him, concealed the things he knew in accordance with propriety, besides avoiding the accusations launched by the group of hypocrites. Even so, the Prophet Muhammad still received criticism from Allah, as is known in the verse in Surah al-Ahzab.

In short, verse 67 threatens those who conceal Allah's trust, as stated in His word:

"Indeed, those who conceal what We sent down of clear proofs and guidance after We made it clear for the people in the Scripture - those are cursed by Allah and cursed by those who curse." (al-Baqarah/2:159).

In line with this threat from the Qur'an, the Prophet Muhammad said, reminding those who conceal knowledge:

Whoever is asked about some knowledge and then conceals it, he will be restrained on the Day of Resurrection with a restraint of fire from hell. (Narrated by Abu Daud, at-Tirmidhi from Abu Hurairah).

Furthermore, the end of this verse affirms that Allah will not guide the disbelievers who disturb the Prophet Muhammad, and their work will surely be in vain because Allah will continue to protect His Prophet and will continue to exalt His word.
text.68:
In this verse, Allah commands Muhammad to say to the People of the Book that they cannot be considered religious as long as they do not uphold the teachings of the Torah, the Gospel, and the teachings that have been revealed to the Prophet Muhammad, namely the Al-Qur'an. Because if they upheld the teachings of the Torah and the Gospel, there would be no group they would oppose and curse. If someone else bothered them, they would certainly forgive, even offering their left cheek when someone struck their right cheek.

They would not compete in preparing weapons that destroy the world for the sake of human safety in the world. For peace, they would certainly spend their wealth. But the reality that their behavior is the opposite shows that they are not people who adhere to religion. In fact, most of them increase in wickedness and disbelief towards what Allah has revealed to the Prophet Muhammad, namely the Al-Qur'an, as the book that perfects Allah's religion. This illustrates that they do not truly believe in Allah and do not truly believe in the messengers. In short, they do not perform the good deeds required by their Books. So most of them only adhere to bad customs and fanaticism, therefore they reject the Al-Qur'an, consciously because they are far from the true teachings of their religion.

The religion before Muhammad is the foundation of the religion brought by the Prophet Muhammad because Islam is the perfection of previous religions. Because they see the Al-Qur'an through the lens of hostility and fanaticism, their fanaticism and wickedness increase. Indeed, there is a small group of them who maintain the teachings of Tawhid, who love the truth; these are the people who view the Al-Qur'an with awareness because they believe that the Al-Qur'an is truly from their Lord and that the Prophet to whom the Al-Qur'an was revealed is the last Prophet written in their books, so they believe in Muhammad like the Jewish scholars and Najasyi and the Christian circles.

Furthermore, the end of this verse forbids the Prophet Muhammad from grieving over the disbelievers who do not respond to his call for them to believe in the Al-Qur'an.
text.69:
This verse, in terms of its meaning, is no different from verse 62 of Surah al-Baqarah. It is repeated, with a different arrangement. In line with the previous verse, verse 62, which commands Muhammad to say to the People of the Book that they are not considered religious as long as they do not truly believe in Allah and practice the guidance of the Torah and the Gospel, as well as the teachings of the Qur'an, in this verse Allah explains that this applies to the followers of all the messengers before Muhammad, namely the Jews, Christians, and Sabi'in (those who are neither Jews nor Christians). If they followed the guidance of their religions before it was altered by their hands, then they would not fear on the Day of Judgment. And those who met the Prophet Muhammad but opposed him or pretended to believe, if they repent and do good deeds, then they will not fear on the Day of Judgment, because no one has any advantage except if they believe in Allah and the Last Day and do good deeds.

Humans have two kinds of strength: first, strength in the field of theory, and second, strength in the field of practice or *amaliah*. Strength in the field of theory only reaches its perfection if a person has knowledge. Human knowledge only reaches perfection if it reaches knowledge of the most noble thing, namely Allah, the One God, the Almighty, who resurrects and gathers mankind in the *padang mahsyar* (the plain of assembly). Thus, the most noble knowledge is faith in Allah and the Last Day. The most noble good deed is devotion to Allah and striving to convey beneficial things to mankind. So, those who face Allah with faith and such deeds will certainly not fear in the slightest the chaos and disasters of the Day of Judgment, and they will not grieve over the pleasures of the world that they never experienced when they lived in the world.
text.70:
This verse explains that Allah took a covenant from the Children of Israel, which was their pledge to believe in Allah and practice the contents of the Torah as the sharia that Allah revealed to them. To provide clarification of the contents of the book, Allah sent His messengers to them. But every time a messenger came to them bringing guidance that did not align with their desires, they treated the messenger with very cruel treatment.

A group of them denied the messengers, and some of them persecuted and killed the messengers. This shows how evil their behavior was, so that the guidance brought by the messenger did not make the slightest impression on their hearts; instead, their disbelief and injustice only increased.
text.71:
This verse explains that the Jews did not expect Allah to give them a severe trial because of their heinous deeds and excessive cruelty, because they considered themselves the children of Allah and His beloved, therefore they considered themselves free from Allah's punishment. They were as if blind to the realities that showed Allah's punishments for people who caused destruction and injustice. They were as if deaf to the teachings and guidance that were full of Allah's threats; namely, punishment for those who break the promises they have made because of following their desires to commit injustice.

Historically, when the Babylonian nation was under the rule of Nebuchadnezzar around 586 BC, they conquered the Jewish nation, destroyed the Temple of Solomon in Jerusalem, plundered property, and raped women. Only after the Jews returned to the teachings of the Torah and repented to Allah, did Allah give them help to escape the cruelty of the Babylonian nation. But after their sight was blinded to warnings, and their ears were deaf to Allah's guidance, they returned to committing injustice, killing the messengers, then Allah's trial came again, namely that they were alternately controlled by the Roman empire. Indeed, not all Jews committed evil, as evidenced by the existence of a small group of them who did good, but it has become *sunnatullah* that God's trial befalls the entire community equally as a result of the actions of the unjust group. Allah has warned in His word:

"And guard yourselves against a punishment which does not fall exclusively on those of you who are wrongdoers." (al-Anfal/8:25).

Furthermore, the end of this verse explains that Allah is All-Seeing of the actions or behavior of the Jews towards the Prophet Muhammad, whether in the form of deception or in the form of mobilizing all the tribes to unite to attack the Prophet Muhammad, because of the encouragement of their evil desires that have made them blind, when evidence of the truth was presented by the Prophet Muhammad as the final Prophet of all prophets.
text.72:
Allah affirms with certainty that the Christians are disbelievers because they believe that Allah is Isa Almasih (Jesus Christ), the son of Maryam (Mary). This stance is what makes them disbelievers and astray, because they excessively praise Isa a.s. (peace be upon him), just as the Jews excessively insult Isa, especially towards Maryam. The stance of the Christians towards the prophet Isa a.s. is a stance adopted by the majority of Christian groups, and anyone among them who deviates from this stance is considered an apostate. The Christians believe that God consists of elements they call three persons, namely the Father, the Son, and the Holy Spirit. Isa is the son, Allah is the Father who incarnated in the son who is the Holy Spirit, and they are three inseparable entities. Thus, Allah is Isa and Isa is Allah. This stance of theirs is very deviant from the truth, because Isa himself said to the Children of Israel that they should worship Allah, who is the Lord of Isa and the Lord of the Children of Israel. So this verse clearly shows a direct acknowledgement from Isa that the God to be worshipped is Allah alone. In short, the calls of the Prophet Isa to the Children of Israel, as explained by this verse, are to affirm the religion of Tawhid (Oneness of God). This can be seen in the original Gospels. In the New Testament, Mark xii. 28-30, when a scribe asked Jesus, "The most important is, 'Hear, O Israel: The Lord our God, the Lord is one. And you shall love the Lord your God with all your heart and with all your soul and with all your mind and with all your strength.'" Likewise, Matthew iv.10, Jesus rebuked Satan for wanting to worship other than Allah, Luke xviii. 19 and John xx.17.

Furthermore, Allah explains that Isa explicitly said that those who associate partners with Allah, whether with angels or with stars or with stones, will not enter Paradise and their place is in Hell, because those who associate partners with Allah are those who wrong themselves, and therefore do not deserve defense or help from Allah.
text.73:
This verse explains that Allah affirms the disbelief of the Christians who say that Allah, who created the heavens and the earth, is one of three persons: the Father, the Son, and the Holy Spirit. Thus, this verse depicts the stance of the majority of Christians in the past. A small group of them believed that Allah is Isa, the son of Maryam, while another small group believed that Isa is the Son of Allah, and he is not Allah.

Their belief has no strong basis because the true God is a Being that cannot be numbered. Allah is One. Therefore, Allah is All-Powerful. If God is numbered, it means that the All-Powerful is more than one, and if there are two or more of them, they would surely compete for power, which would result in the destruction of the universe. If those gods were to make peace, meaning that one has power in the heavens and another has power on earth, it would mean that God is weak, because the characteristic of peace is a characteristic of the weak who are unable to conquer the universe alone. Thus, the All-Powerful must be singular.

Furthermore, if God is numbered, for example, consisting of three persons and all three are considered one because of their unity, it means that if one of them is lost, their unity is lost. Thus, their divinity is lost because of the death of Jesus (one of the persons of God) on the cross. If this is not the case, it means that God is numbered. So, there is a God who has died on the cross and two who are still alive.

If the existence of God the Father and the existence of God the Son are justified, then the one called God the Father must be known to exist first, and the one called God the Son must be known to exist later. Meanwhile, God is characterized by *Qadim*, which means "His existence is not preceded by non-existence," and God is characterized by *Baqa* (eternal), which means "His existence is not ended by non-existence." Isa was preceded by "non-existence," therefore he is not characterized by *Qadim*, because he did not exist before being born by Maryam, and Isa is not characterized by *baqa* (eternal) because he has become non-existent, he has died.

Thus, is the error of the Christian belief, when viewed from a logical perspective. Therefore, in this verse, Allah warns the Christians to abandon their false beliefs, and they should return to the teachings of *Tauhid*. If they persist in disbelief, namely associating partners with Allah, they will be thrown into the torment of the fire of Hell.
text.74: This verse explains that the behavior of the Jews is very astonishing because they have received verses containing reproaches accompanied by threats, yet their hearts are not moved to return to Allah and seek His forgiveness, even though Allah's Mercy is vast, the Most Forgiving, the Most Accepting of repentance from His servants who are immersed in error and then truly believe and are pious, accompanied by righteous deeds.
text.75:
This verse explains the special position of Al-Masih (Isa/Jesus) and the special position of his mother (Maryam/Mary), then this verse also explains the reality of their personalities. The special characteristic of Al-Masih is that he is a messenger of Allah, no different from the messengers who came before him, because each brought signs of apostleship from Allah. If Allah gave Prophet Isa the ability to heal leprosy and raise the dead as a miracle for Al-Masih, then Allah made his staff into a snake (al-A'raf/7:107) and split the sea (al-Baqarah/2:50) as a miracle for Prophet Musa/Moses. If Al-Masih was created without a father, then Prophet Adam was created without a mother and father. The mother of Al-Masih is a very noble person and devoted to Allah.

This verse affirms that Al-Masih is like the other messengers, ordinary humans who have physical needs, including eating food to avoid hunger and maintaining health for the continuation of life. Everyone needs something, he is an ordinary creature, therefore he cannot be said to be the Creator God and is not worthy of being worshipped. So, the only one who is worthy and has the right to be worshipped is Allah the Almighty because Allah's help is needed. Everything that is needed is certainly considered noble by those who need it. In short, the worshipper is someone who considers himself lower and more despicable than the one being worshipped. Al-Masih is very well known for his strong devotion to Allah, so Al-Masih worships Allah, this shows that Al-Masih is "not Allah" because Allah is the one who is worshipped. It is foolish for someone to worship someone who is equal to him, both in the essence of creation and in needing help.

Furthermore, at the end of this verse, Allah explains to Muhammad saw, how Allah explains to the People of the Book about the signs of His power which show the error of their stance on Al-Masih. Then Allah asks the Prophet Muhammad to pay attention to how the People of the Book reject the explanations that Allah has put forward, which shows that they are not using healthy reasoning because they are bound by blind imitation (taqlid buta).
text.76:
This verse explains how misguided the Christians are in worshipping Al-Masih (the Messiah). Muhammad received a command from Allah to ask the Christians why they worship other than Allah, something that can neither harm nor benefit. Do they not know that the Jews were hostile to Al-Masih and wanted to destroy him, while Al-Masih himself was apparently unable to harm the Jews, and Al-Masih's companions could not help him? Is it reasonable to consider someone who has no such ability as God? Do they not themselves recount that when Jesus was persecuted on the cross, he asked for water because he was thirsty, and the Jews only gave him vinegar poured into his nostrils? (Mark xv. 36: "Then someone ran, filled a sponge with wine vinegar, put it on a staff, and offered it to Jesus to drink. 'Now leave him alone. Let’s see if Elijah comes to take him down,' he said." Also found in Matthew xxvii. 48, John xix. 29-30). Does not this story of theirs show that Jesus was very weak? Is it fitting for someone as weak as this to be considered God?

Furthermore, the end of this verse warns the Christians that Allah is All-Hearing, especially of their words of disbelief, and All-Knowing of the falsehood that is in their hearts.
text.77:
In this verse, Allah forbids the People of the Book who, during the time of Prophet Muhammad, acted excessively in religion as their ancestors had done before, and forbids them from following the reasons that led their ancestors to error, thus leading others astray from the path of truth (the teachings of Islam). They abandoned the laws of the Sharia and followed their evil desires. Thus, from this verse, it can be concluded that the People of the Book are:

a. People who have been misguided since ancient times because they followed their desires in religious matters, created *bid'ah* (innovations), legalized what is forbidden, and abandoned the *sunnah* of the Messenger.

b. Others become misguided because, after being misguided themselves, they try to mislead others, expanding the *bid'ah* that was created by their priests.

c. People who turn away from the religion of Islam, continuously remain in error, meaning they have transgressed, committed *bid'ah*, and deviated from correct belief (*itikad*).
text.78: This verse explains that the disbelievers from among the Jews received the wrath and curse of Allah through the words of Prophet David and Jesus, son of Mary. When the Jews committed wickedness on the Sabbath (the day when Jews were forbidden from catching fish), Prophet David cursed them specifically for violating the sanctity of the Sabbath and generally for those who committed ordinary wickedness. (Psalms cix. 17-18,/xxviii. 21-22, 31-33,/xiv. 22-28, and passim). Prophet Jesus also cursed them as "descendants of the murderers of the prophets" and "You snakes! You brood of vipers!" (Matthew xxiii. 31-35). At the end of this verse, it is explained that the curse was because they committed disobedience and violated the laws of Allah in an excessive manner.
text.79:
This verse explains that the habit of the Jews was to allow evil to occur in their presence because they did not carry out *amar makruf nahi mungkar* (enjoining good and forbidding evil). So evil were their actions that it became the reason for Allah's curse upon them. In relation to this verse, the Prophet Muhammad said,

From Abdullah bin Masud r.a. he said, the Messenger of Allah SAW said: "When the Children of Israel fell into the valley of sin, then their scholars forbade them, but they did not stop. Then the scholars became close to them, sitting, eating, and drinking together. Allah SWT then made their hearts close to each other and cursed them all through the tongue of David and Jesus, son of Mary. This was because they disobeyed and transgressed." Abdullah bin Masud then said: The Prophet SAW then sat down, previously he was leaning, then said: "No, by the One who controls my soul, until you truly subdue them to the truth." (Narrated by Abu Dawud, at-Tirmizi and Ibn Majah. According to at-Tirmizi, this hadith is hasan)
text.80: After the previous verse explained the bad behavior of the ancestors of the Jews (Bani Israil), this verse explains that the Prophet Muhammad witnessed firsthand the behavior of the disbelieving Bani Israil people who existed in his time, namely that most of them helped each other with the polytheists from the Arab community (the Prophet's own people) in the effort to fight the Prophet Muhammad. The work they did was very bad because they only followed the dictates of their desires and incitement. This action aroused the wrath of Allah, for which they would surely receive a reward from Him in the form of the torment of hellfire forever. Those who are free from the fire of hell are those who do work that is pleasing to Allah.
text.81: This verse explains that if the Jewish community, who were helping each other with the Arab polytheists, truly believed in the Prophet Moses as they claimed, and believed in the teachings brought by the Prophet Moses, then they would not be helping each other with the polytheists who worshipped idols. Because their pure religious teachings could not justify that. But most of them were wicked people (fasiq), which is why they could unite and cooperate, bound by a common interest: opposing the Prophet Muhammad, rejecting the teachings of the Qur'an, and trying to deter those who believed in Muhammad.
text.82:
In this verse, Allah informs Prophet Muhammad that in his struggle, he will find that the people most hostile and harmful to the believers are the Jews of Medina, the Arab polytheists, and idol worshippers. Both the Jews and the Arab polytheists opposed Muhammad's teachings. This commonality bound these two groups together, even though they each possessed opposing personality traits. Furthermore, this verse informs Prophet Muhammad that he will find the people closest to and most fond of the believers are the Christians. The reason is that among them are those who pay attention to religious teachings and good character, namely the monastic orders who are against worldly luxuries. They are pious and spend much time in meditation for worship. Naturally, both of these groups are humble because their religion encourages loving one's enemies and offering the left cheek to those who strike the right cheek. The goodness of the Christians has been proven by history, namely the welcome of the King of Abyssinia (Ethiopia), called Najashi, who embraced Christianity. He and his companions protected the Muslims who first migrated from Mecca to Abyssinia out of fear of the harassment and slander perpetrated by the Arab polytheists cruelly.

The Roman Emperor of the East in Syria, Heraclius, when he received the letter from Prophet Muhammad, welcomed it with a good reception and tried to provide explanations to his people so that they could accept Prophet Muhammad's invitation, even though the people did not yet agree with him because they still adhered to fanaticism. Muqawqis, who ruled Egypt, also welcomed the Prophet's letter with a good reception, even though he was not yet willing to accept the Prophet's invitation to Islam. However, he answered the Prophet's letter and sent valuable gifts, including a *jariah* (female slave) named Mariah al-Qibtiyah. Such was the reception of the Christians in the Prophet's time. This is in stark contrast to the Jews, who, although they reluctantly expressed sympathy towards the believers, harbored deceitful thoughts in their hearts to deceive the believers. Because the teachings of the Jewish leaders instilled in them nationalistic fanaticism and the belief that the Children of Israel (*Bani Israil*) are the only nation chosen by Allah.
text.83:
This verse explains that when Christians hear and understand the content of the verses of the Qur'an, some of them shed tears because they are deeply moved and convinced of the truth of the Qur'an revealed by Allah to the Prophet Muhammad, which turns out to confirm their holy book. They are also moved by the characteristics of the Prophet Muhammad that they had previously known from their holy book. At that moment, they humbly say, "Our Lord, we believe in You and in Your messengers, especially the Prophet Muhammad. Therefore, include us with those who acknowledge the truth of the Qur'an and the Prophet Muhammad, who will be witnesses on the Day of Judgment that You have truly sent Your prophets and messengers, and that they have truly conveyed Your religion to their respective peoples."

Furthermore, they state that nothing can prevent them from believing in Allah and in the truth that has been revealed through His last Messenger who was sent to all of mankind. Then they also affirm that they believe in Allah and in the truth brought by His Messenger, because they earnestly desire that Allah include them in the group of righteous people, namely the ummah of the Prophet Muhammad, because of the true teachings of Islam, both regarding faith, worship, *mu'amalah* and noble character.
text.84:
This verse explains that when Christians hear and understand the contents of the verses of the Qur'an, some of them shed tears because they are deeply moved and convinced of the truth of the Qur'an revealed by Allah to the Prophet Muhammad, which turns out to confirm their holy book. They are also moved by the characteristics of the Prophet Muhammad that they had previously known from their holy book. At that moment, they humbly say, "Our Lord, we believe in You and in Your messengers, especially the Prophet Muhammad. Therefore, include us with those who acknowledge the truth of the Qur'an and the Prophet Muhammad, who will be witnesses on the Day of Judgment that You have indeed sent Your prophets and messengers, and that they have truly conveyed Your religion to their respective peoples."

Furthermore, they state that nothing can prevent them from believing in Allah and in the truth that has been revealed through His last Messenger who was sent to all mankind. Then they also affirm that they believe in Allah and in the truth brought by His Messenger, because they earnestly desire that Allah include them in the group of righteous people, namely the ummah of the Prophet Muhammad, because of the true teachings of Islam, both regarding faith, worship, *mu'amalah* and noble character.
text.85: Based on their words expressing their faith and their sincere devotion to Allah, Allah gives them a reward, in the form of Paradise where they obtain the pleasure and bounty of Allah in the form of beautiful gardens and parks. In essence, the beauty and pleasure they obtain in Paradise cannot be described with words. Paradise will be bestowed by Allah upon His servants who believe and do righteous deeds during their lifetime in the world.
text.86: Christians who believe in Allah and the Qur'an are those who are willing to think, are aware, and are not fanatical. But there are those who are fanatical about falsehood and deny the truth, they deny the Qur'an. They are the People of the Book, namely Jews and Christians whose hearts are closed to accepting the truth, they only feel they are right. In this verse, Allah mentions His threat to those who deny and reject His verses that have explained the attributes of His perfection and oneness, and explained the truth of His Messenger regarding the revelation of Allah that he has conveyed. They will surely be inhabitants of Hellfire (Jahim). With their disbelief in Allah, it means they have wronged themselves. As a result, they will suffer severe punishment, and they will abide therein forever.
text.87:
This verse was revealed concerning several companions who were mistaken in understanding and practicing the teachings of Islam. They thought that to draw closer to Allah, they had to detach themselves from all worldly pleasures, because they believed that these pleasures would only distract them from worshipping Allah. However, Allah has created and provided on earth good things that He has made lawful for them. In addition, He has also explained what He has forbidden. Although Allah has provided and made lawful good things for His servants, they must still be treated in a reasonable and not excessive manner. Therefore, Allah's word in this verse forbids His servants from attitudes and actions that are excessive.

Excessive behavior in matters of food, for example, can be interpreted in two ways. First, a person continues to eat good, halal food, but he eats too much of it, or too much. Whereas eating too much can damage health, the digestive system, and possibly the mind. His funds and thoughts are only focused on food and drink, so that other obligations are neglected, especially his worship. The second meaning is that a person has exceeded the limits in the variety and type of food he eats, the drinks he drinks; no longer limited to good and halal food, but has even exceeded it to what is destructive and dangerous, which has been forbidden by religion. Both of these are not justified by Islamic teachings.

At the end of the verse, Allah warns His servants that He does not like those who transgress. This means that every work we do must always be within the limits set by religion, such as the limits of halal and haram, as well as the limits that can be known by reason, thought and feeling, for example, the limits regarding how much or how little, and its benefits and harms.

One thing we need to remember is the principle contained in Islamic Sharia, that what is made lawful by religion is because it is beneficial and not dangerous; conversely, what is forbidden is because it is dangerous and not beneficial, or because its danger is greater than its benefit. Therefore, it is not permissible to change the religious laws that have been established by Allah and His Messenger. Allah knows best what is good and beneficial for His servants and what is dangerous for them. He is Most Merciful towards them.
text.88:
In this verse, Allah commands His servants to eat from the lawful and good sustenance that He has bestowed upon them. "Halal" here implies that the substance itself is halal and the way of obtaining it is halal. While "good" refers to its benefits, meaning it contains benefits and advantages for the body, containing nutrients, vitamins, protein, and so on. Food that is not good, besides not containing nutrients, will also damage health if consumed.

The principle of "halal and good" should always be a concern in determining the food and drinks to be consumed for oneself and for the family, because food and drinks not only affect the physical, but also the spiritual.

Every flesh that grows from something haram, then the Fire is better for it. (Narrated by at-Tirmidzi)

There is no obstacle for believers who are able, to enjoy delicious food and drinks, and to have relations with their wives, but they must obey the provisions that have been set by the Sharia, namely: good, halal and according to a reasonable measure and not excessive. Therefore, at the end of this verse, Allah warns believers to be careful and fear Him in the matter of food, drink, and other pleasures. Let them not establish laws according to their own desires and not be excessive in enjoying what He has made lawful.

In another verse, Allah says:

eat and drink, but do not be excessive. Indeed, Allah does not like those who are excessive. (al-A'raf/7: 31)

The Islamic religion highly prioritizes simplicity. It does not justify its people being excessive in eating, drinking, dressing, and so on, even in worship. Conversely, it also does not justify someone from being too restrained from enjoying something, even though he is able to obtain it. Especially if the nature of restraint leads him to forbid what the Sharia has made lawful.

Every believer is commanded by Allah swt. to always consume food that is halal and good (containing sufficient nutrients and vitamins). So the part of the verse that reads halal and good (Arabic: *halalan thayyiba*) above contains the meaning of two aspects that will be attached to every sustenance of food consumed by humans. The first aspect is that food should be obtained in a halal way that is in accordance with Islamic law as exemplified by the Messenger. In this case, it contains a command to conduct proper muamalah. Do not use force, deception, theft, or in ways that are forbidden in Islamic law. Meanwhile, in the good or *thayyib* aspect, it is from the side of the content of food substances consumed. Food should contain substances needed by the body, both in quality and quantity. Balanced nutrition food is recommended. There is food that is halal but not *thayyib*, for example, the Messenger exemplified that the head, skin and offal of slaughtered animals should be discarded. He even said do not eat bones because bones are food for your brothers from the jinn. Research shows that these parts actually contain many substances that cause blood cholesterol levels in the human body to increase rapidly.

The Messenger of Allah has given an example of this simplicity. In all aspects of his life, he was always simple, even though if he wanted to, he could have enjoyed all kinds of pleasures to his heart's content. But he did not do so, because as a leader, he led and gave an example to his people, a simple lifestyle, but not torturing himself.
text.89:
In this verse, it is explained that Allah will not impose punishment on someone who violates an oath that was not uttered sincerely or was not preceded by the intention to swear. However, if someone swears with all their heart and sincere intention, and then violates that oath, they are subject to *kaffarat* (atonement), which is one of the following:

a) Feeding ten poor people, each one meal. (Imam Abu Hanifah allows feeding only one poor person, but for ten days). The food must be of the same quality as the food eaten daily by the one paying the *kaffarat* and their family.

b) Providing clothing to ten poor people, of the same quality as the clothing they wear daily.

c) Freeing a slave who was obtained by purchase or captured in war. It is not stipulated here that the slaves must be believers. Therefore, it is permissible to free even a non-believing slave as *kaffarat* for violating an oath. (This is the opinion of Imam Abu Hanifah. While Imam Shafi'i, Malik, and Ahmad require that the slave be a believer).

d) Fasting for three days. This applies to the oath-breaker who is unable to pay their oath *kaffarat* with one of the three types of *kaffarat* mentioned earlier. If they are not yet able to fast because they are sick, then it must be done after they recover and are able to fast. If it turns out that their illness does not heal, and then they die before having the opportunity to fast to pay the *kaffarat*, then Allah's forgiveness is hoped for them, if they truly had a sincere intention to carry it out, even though it was not achieved.

Thus, it is clear that someone who violates an oath that was indeed intended sincerely must pay *kaffarat*, one of the three types of *kaffarat*. If they are unable, they may pay it with the fourth *kaffarat*, which is fasting for three consecutive days. Regarding this, the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) explained with his saying narrated by Ibn Mardawaih from Ibn 'Abbas, who said:

When the verse of *kaffarat* was revealed, Hudzaifah asked the Prophet, "Are we allowed to choose?" Then the Prophet replied, "You are allowed to choose, if you want, you may free a slave; and if you want, you may feed (ten poor people). Whoever is unable, then they must fast for three consecutive days." (Narrated by Ibn Mardawaih)

If one swears not to do something that is permissible for them, thus meaning they are rejecting something that Allah has made lawful, then they are obligated to break their oath, and are also obligated to pay its *kaffarat*. The same applies conversely.

After Allah explains the various types of *kaffarat* mentioned above that must be fulfilled by the person who violates their oath, Allah then warns the believers to guard their oaths. Meaning: one should not trifle with oaths. Oaths should only be used in matters that truly require an oath as reinforcement or affirmation.

If an oath has been uttered with sincere intention, then the content of the oath must be fulfilled, unless the oath violates religious rules, for example: to prohibit what Allah and His Messenger have made lawful. Only in such circumstances should the oath be broken, but it must be redeemed with *kaffarat*.

At the end of this verse, Allah explains His verses containing religious laws to those who are willing to be grateful to Him for all His mercy, His justice, and His compassion. It is hoped that gratitude done in the ways He has taught will cause an increase in that mercy towards them.
text.90:
With this verse, Allah explains His laws regarding four types of actions: drinking khamar (intoxicants), gambling, offering sacrifices to idols, and divining luck using tools resembling arrows, which was a common practice among the Arabs before the advent of Islam.

Regarding the prohibition of drinking khamar, the scholars of tafsir (Quranic exegesis) are of the opinion that this verse represents the final stage in determining the haram (forbidden) status of drinking khamar. According to them, the Quran presents the law concerning drinking khamar in four stages.

First, in the form of information about the presence of alcohol in grapes in Surah an-Nahl/16:67.

Second, the benefits and harms of alcoholic beverages:

"They ask you (Muhammad) about khamar and gambling. Say, "In them is great sin and [yet, some] benefit for people. But their sin is greater than their benefit." (al-Baqarah/2: 219)

This verse was revealed in the early days of Islam, when the faith of the Muslims was not yet strong enough to abandon what had become their habits and customs, which were actually not permitted by Islam. So after this verse was revealed, some of the Muslims abandoned the habit of drinking khamar because the verse mentioned that the act was a major sin. But some continued the habit of drinking khamar, because in their opinion the verse had not yet forbidden them from doing so, because it still mentioned that khamar contained many benefits for humans.

The alcohol or khamr referred to is ethanol produced by fermenting fruit juices such as grapes, pineapples, and so on. It can also be produced from molasses, waste from sugar cane factories, and this is the most widely used raw material for producing alcohol in Indonesia.

Alcohol has several benefits, including as a source of energy and a solvent. Alcohol is a fairly high source of energy, higher than sugar and almost equal to fat with the following ratios: Carbohydrates/sugar, 4 kcal/g, alcohol, 7 kcal/g and fat, 9 kcal/g. In addition, alcohol is easily digested so the body easily obtains energy after drinking alcohol. Alcohol is also used as a solvent in medicines called elixirs, such as in the kidney medicine Batugen Elixir or also in cough medicine.

Third, the prohibition of performing prayer while intoxicated:

"O you who have believed, do not approach prayer while you are intoxicated..." (an-Nisa'/4: 43).

Because this verse forbids them from performing prayer in a state of intoxication, this means that they are not allowed to drink khamar before prayer, so that they can perform prayer in a state of sobriety. After this verse was revealed, they could no longer drink khamar from before Dhuhr prayer until the completion of Isha prayer, because the times for Dhuhr and Asr are connected, in a short period. Likewise between Asr and Maghrib, and between Maghrib and Isha. If they drank khamar after Dhuhr or Maghrib prayer, there would not be enough time to wait for them to recover from intoxication. Thus, they would not be able to perform prayer in a state of sobriety, while Allah has forbidden them from performing prayer in a state of intoxication.

People who wanted to drink khamar only had the opportunity after Isha prayer and after Fajr prayer. Because the distance between Isha and Fajr and between Fajr and Dhuhr is quite long. Thus, it is hoped that the number of people drinking khamar will decrease.

Fourth, the establishment of the prohibition of khamar:

After the faith of the Muslims became stronger, and their psychology became more stable to abandon what was not permitted by religion, then verse 90 of Surah al-Ma'idah/5 was revealed, which provides clarity about the haram status of drinking khamar, namely by saying that drinking khamar, and other actions are filthy, haram actions and are among the deeds of Satan that are not worthy of being done by humans who believe in Allah. With the revelation of this verse, all possibilities for the believers to drink khamar were closed.

These are the stages that the Quran has arranged in giving the law of prohibition of drinking khamar. This principle is very appropriate to use if we want to carry out eradication and extermination of what has taken root and become ingrained in society. If we take drastic action, sudden and simultaneous eradication, there will be upheaval in society, and there will be strong resistance to the new regulations to be implemented. Islam places great importance on building human mentality, and avoiding the emergence of upheavals in society.

Khamar or alcoholic beverages are prohibited because behind their benefits, alcohol also has harms.
