In developed countries, such as America and Australia, alcohol causes more than 55% of traffic accidents and is also a source of various diseases. In America, it was identified that drunkards suffer from many diseases due to avitaminosis. In Australia, it was found that the children of drunkard husbands and wives suffer from physical and/or mental disabilities. In Papua New Guinea, the drinking habits of its workers are the cause of divorce, because money is spent on drinking. In Indonesia, alcohol is the cause of criminal acts such as robbery, rape and murder. Also the cause of traffic accidents, and broken homes. Although it is a big business, it has been researched that every dollar earned from alcohol products requires a greater cost to overcome the social damage obtained, such as:

Tennese State: Earnings US$1,- cost US$ 2.28

Shelby State: Earnings US$1,- cost US$ 11.08

Memphis State: Earnings US$1,- cost US$ 4.39

Because alcohol is easily absorbed, excess food such as sugar, fat and protein is stored in the form of fat, leading to excess weight. This obesity is the cause of blood vessel, heart and sugar (diabetes) diseases.

It should be noted that alcohol is a high-energy drink but without nutrition or called "empty calories". Also, alcohol causes the body to not be able to absorb vitamins and minerals or both are excreted in the urine. As a result, drunkards become malnourished. And this is also the main reason that the children of drinkers or drunkards suffer from physical or mental disabilities because their sperm or ovum is malnourished.

Continuous detoxification of alcohol in the body by the liver can damage cells. Cell damage will disrupt liver performance. In addition, excess fat is stored in the liver which can cause liver cancer or cirrhosis for which there is no cure.

Alcohol damages the nervous system, weakens muscle and eye coordination (the cause of accidents). It also eliminates memory so that it commits all kinds of crimes without awareness, such as raping, fighting, robbing and killing.

Alcohol is a substance that causes addiction or is addictive. This nature causes drinkers to want to consume more and more because they are not satisfied. This feeling of always being dissatisfied is what ultimately leads to the world of narcotics such as marijuana, morphine, cocaine, and so on. This addictive nature has not been satisfactorily explained scientifically.

As for gambling, it is very dangerous for individuals and society. Gambling can damage a person's personality and morals, because a gambler always dreams of getting big profits without working and trying, spending his life at the gambling table without regard for his health, his life's needs and the lives of his family which causes the household to be destroyed. Gambling will cause hostility between fellow gamblers. This hostility continues in social interaction, thus damaging society. How many households are broken, wealth is destroyed because of gambling. No one is rich solely because of gambling (see also the interpretation of verse 219 of Surah al-Baqarah/2).

The Arabs before Islam were a society of idol worshipers. They made statues from stone and so on, then they worshiped and glorified them. They slaughtered sacrificial animals to be offered to these statues. This act is a misguided act. Because only Allah deserves to be worshiped and glorified. Humans can worship Allah, without intermediaries. If you want to sacrifice, slaughter the sacrifice, then the meat is distributed to people who can benefit from it, not to statues that will not be able to take any benefit from the sacrificial meat. Therefore, it is very appropriate that Islam forbids Muslims from offering sacrifices to statues, then Islam stipulates that the sacrifice is to glorify Allah, and the meat is distributed to fellow humans.

Divining luck is also an act that has long been known to humans, and even now it is still done and believed by some people. There are various ways used for this purpose. Sometimes by using tools, or by examining the palms of the hands, or by paying attention to the dates and days of birth of the stars, as is often listed in entertainment magazines or newspapers. The Arabs in the Jahiliyyah era used to divine luck using azlam, which are arrows that have not been feathered. They used them to make decisions about whether they would do something or not. The method is: they take three arrows that have not been feathered, then on the first arrow they write the words "do it" while on the second arrow they write the words "do not do it"; as for the third arrow, nothing is written on it. The three arrows are placed in a container, then stored inside the Ka'bah. When they want to do a job, they ask the Ka'bah key holder to take one of the three arrows. Whether they will do the act or not, depends on the writing found on the arrow that is taken. If it turns out that the one taken is the arrow that has no writing, then the lottery is repeated once again. Thus, they depend their fate on the lottery and they greatly believe in it.

Such lotteries and predictions contain many negative aspects. If the fortune teller says that the person concerned will meet a bad fate, then it will make him feel worried, afraid and desperate, and will even cause him not to want to work and try because he believes in the prediction. Conversely, if the fortune teller says that he will become a rich and happy person, then it can cause him to be lazy to work and look down on all kinds of efforts, because he believes that even without effort he will be happy or become rich.

Believers are forbidden to believe in these predictions, whether said directly by fortune tellers, or commonly published in print and electronic media. These predictions can damage faith. Believers must believe that only Allah can determine the fate of every creature. Believing in Allah's qadha and qadar is one of the pillars of faith.

At the end of this verse, Allah commands believers to stay away from drinking khamar, gambling, sacrificing to idols, and divining luck, in the hope that by staying away from these actions, they will become successful and fortunate people in this world and in the hereafter.
text.91:
This verse mentions the reasons why Allah has forbidden drinking khamar (intoxicants) and gambling for the believers. The reasons mentioned in this verse are twofold: First, because through these two acts, Satan wants to incite enmity and hatred among people. Second, because they will distract them from remembering Allah and prayer.

In another verse, it has been mentioned that drinking khamar and gambling are abominations and are among the deeds of Satan. This means that it is Satan who tempts people to do them so that enmity and hatred arise among them.

The emergence of these various dangers in people who like to drink khamar and gamble is undeniable. The reality experienced by such people is sufficient proof. A drinker of khamar is certainly a drunkard. A person who is drunk certainly loses consciousness. A person who loses consciousness easily commits inappropriate acts or utters words that should not be uttered. His actions and words often harm others, thus causing enmity between them. On the other hand, a person who is drunk certainly does not remember to perform worship and dhikr, or if he does, it is certainly in an incorrect and not solemn way. Moreover, drinking alcohol causes addiction and can even make a person dependent, meaning he cannot work without drinking first.

A person who likes to gamble usually always hopes to win. Therefore, he never gives up on that act, as long as he still has money or goods to bet. When his money or goods are exhausted, he will try to take the rights of others in an unlawful way. How many company employees or workers have been found to have corrupted money that they spent at the gambling table. Among the gamblers themselves, there is a sense of enmity, because each wants to defeat his opponent, or wants to take revenge on the opponent who has defeated him. A gambler certainly often forgets worship, because those who are engrossed in gambling will not stop their game to perform worship, because their hearts have submitted to Satan who is constantly trying to prevent people from worshiping Allah and wants them at the gambling table.

In this verse, Allah only mentions the dangers of khamar and gambling, while the dangers of offering sacrifices to idols and drawing lots are no longer mentioned. If we examine it carefully, it can be said that this is due to two things.

First, because sacrifices for idols and drawing lots have been mentioned in Allah's word:

"and (forbidden is) that which is sacrificed on stone altars (to other than Allah), and (forbidden is) that you seek division by arrows (azlam); that is wickedness." (al-Ma'idah/5: 3)

These two acts, in that verse, have been declared as "wickedness" (fasiq).

Second, it is because khamar and gambling are very dangerous. That is what is prioritized in the prohibition in this verse, because some Muslims still do it after the revelation of verse 219 of Surah al-Baqarah/2 and verse 43 of Surah an-Nisa'/4, especially regarding khamar.

After explaining the dangers caused by khamar and gambling, Allah, in a questioning tone, warns the believers. "Will you then desist?" The meaning is that after they have been informed about the great dangers of these acts, then they should stop them, because they themselves will bear the consequences, namely losses in this world and in the hereafter. In this world, they will experience losses of property and physical health, as well as enmity and hatred from others towards them; while in the hereafter they will be afflicted with the wrath and punishment of Allah.

In addition to intoxicating khamar drinks, we are also prohibited from consuming several intoxicating substances, such as narcotics and dangerous drugs (narkoba) as well as other addictive drugs, because they can damage body tissues, cause dependence and eliminate consciousness in the perpetrators.

In the hadith book Musnad Ahmad, and Sunan Abi Daud and at-Tirmidzi, it is mentioned in a narration that 'Umar bin Khaththab once prayed to Allah, "O Allah, give us a satisfactory explanation regarding the issue of khamar." Then after the revelation of verse 219 of Surah al-Baqarah/2, the Messenger of Allah recited that verse to him, but he was still not satisfied, and he continued to pray as mentioned above. Likewise, after the revelation of verse (43) of Surah an-Nisa'/4. But after the revelation of verses 90 and 91 of Surah al-Ma'idah/5, he was called and those verses were recited to him. He felt satisfied. After the recitation reached the word of Allah:

"Will you then desist?"

The companions, including 'Umar bin Khaththab, answered, meaning: "We desist, we desist."
text.92:
In this verse, Allah first commands the believers to obey Allah and obey His Messenger, to be careful and protect themselves. This means that they should obey His commands to avoid intoxicants and gambling, as well as other forbidden acts, including sacrificing to idols and drawing lots; and they must also obey the explanations given by His Messenger regarding the verses that have been revealed to him. Regarding the issue of intoxicants, the Messenger of Allah said:

"Every intoxicant is *khamr*, and every *khamr* is forbidden." (Narrated by Muslim)

The command to "be careful" means to protect oneself from the dangers that will befall them if they violate Allah's prohibition regarding intoxicants and gambling, such as addiction and damage to the intestinal walls, as well as the calamities that will be suffered in this world and in the hereafter. It must be remembered that when Allah forbids His servants from something or an action, it is because that action is dangerous and destructive. In another verse, Allah has said:

"Then let those who dissent from the Messenger's command beware, lest a trial befall them or a painful punishment strike them." (an-Nur/24: 63)

After Allah commands the believers to obey Him and obey His Messenger, and to protect themselves from the dangers that will befall them if they violate His laws and the provisions of His Messenger, then at the end of the verse, Allah mentions His threat, that if they turn away from the religion of Allah that has been conveyed by His Messenger, then the responsibility lies with them, not with the Messenger; because the Messenger's duty is only to convey; and Allah is the One who will reckon and recompense all their deeds, both in this world and in the hereafter. In another verse, Allah says to His Messenger:

"But if they turn away, then your duty is only to convey [the message]. And Allah is Seeing of [His] servants." (ali 'Imran/3: 20)

His saying in another verse is:

"Your duty is only to convey [the message], and Ours is the reckoning." (ar-Ra'd/13: 40)
text.93:
In the narration of Ibn Mundhir from Sa'id bin Zubair, the reason for the revelation of this verse is mentioned as follows: "That some companions came to the Messenger of Allah to ask about those who used to drink khamar and they had prepared reasons to present to him, "What is the opinion of the Messenger of Allah regarding Hamzah bin Abdil Muththalib, Mus'ab bin 'Umair and Abdullah bin Jahsy, will they not enter Paradise?" The Messenger of Allah replied, "Indeed, they will enter Paradise." Then they said, "Didn't they used to drink khamar? Why is khamar now forbidden to us, while they enter Paradise even though they used to drink khamar?" Then the Messenger of Allah replied, "Allah has heard what you have said, if He wills, He will answer it." Then verse (90) was revealed, giving a firm ruling on drinking khamar. Regarding the people they mentioned earlier, namely Hamzah, Mus'ab and Abdullah bin Jahsy, Allah revealed this verse.

In this verse, Allah explains the condition of those who used to gamble and drink khamar, but then they believed and did righteous deeds, whether they were still alive or had died when this verse was revealed. They are not sinful and will not be punished for their past actions, as long as they remain pious to Allah and believe in His Messenger, obedient to the laws that have been revealed by Him. Furthermore, they continue to perform the righteous deeds that have been obligated upon them, such as: prayer (salat), fasting (puasa), alms (zakat) and so on. Then they also continue to abstain from what He has forbidden that they have known, such as gambling, drinking khamar, sacrificing to idols, drawing lots and others, and they continue to believe in His verses that explain these laws. Finally, they continuously remain in piety and increase their righteous deeds, namely with various voluntary (sunnah) acts of worship.

Thus, it is clear that bad deeds committed before the prohibition came, or before they knew of the prohibition, do not cause sin for them, as long as they then believe, are pious, and do righteous deeds, both obligatory and voluntary, and they completely avoid actions that are forbidden by religion.

At the end of the verse, Allah explains that He loves those who do good. This means that Allah bestows His mercy upon those who do good, so that they are free from the bad effects caused by gambling and khamar, for example: hatred, animosity and negligence in remembering Allah, performing salat and other acts of worship.
text.94:
This verse explains Allah's test for the believers who are in the state of *ihram*, that they are not allowed to hunt, even though at that time there were many game animals, so they could easily catch them, either with their hands or by using spears.

According to a narration, this verse was revealed when the Muslims were performing the Umrah of Hudaibiyah. When they found on their journey a great number of animals and birds, more than they had ever found before. Small animals could be caught by hand, and large and wild animals could be caught using spears and so on. However, Allah forbade them to catch them. This prohibition was a test for them to prove the strength of their faith and their piety to Him. Those who are truly strong in faith will certainly not violate Allah's prohibitions, either openly or secretly. They are always afraid of Allah's punishment, even though they have never witnessed that punishment.

The end of this verse presents Allah's threat to those who still violate His provisions after the notification and threat, that they will surely receive a painful punishment as a result of that violation.

This test is actually only a light trial, compared to other trials and tests that require the sacrifice of property and life. However, if someone does not pass this small and light test and trial, how can they succeed in undergoing greater trials?

The trials and tests that Allah gives to His servants sometimes require the sacrifice of property and life in doing something He commands, or in the form of losing something that is dearly loved, or requiring willingness to refrain from doing what is desired. The latter is clearly easier to carry out, such as the prohibition imposed on them, namely the prohibition of hunting at a time when game animals are abundant and easy to catch, while they need food for supplies on their journey.
text.95:
This verse affirms Allah's prohibition to the believers, forbidding them from killing game animals that are usually caught and then slaughtered to be eaten. This prohibition is directed at those who are in a state of *ihram*, whether *ihram* for the Hajj pilgrimage or the Umrah pilgrimage.

Then, the penalty imposed on believers who violate this prohibition is explained, namely, those who intentionally kill game animals, knowing that the prohibition exists. The penalty is to fulfill one of the following:

a. Replacing the killed game animal with livestock that is judged to be equivalent to the one that was killed, based on the decision of two just individuals. The replacement animal must be brought to the sacred land (the *haram*), then slaughtered there, and its meat distributed to the poor and needy.

b. An expiation (*kaffarat*) in the form of feeding the poor and needy, with food of equivalent value to the replacement animal mentioned above;

c. Fasting for a number of days equal to the number of measures (*mud*) of food that must be given to the poor and needy, with the understanding that each poor and needy person receives one *mud*, approximately equal to ¾ liter (0.75 liters), with each *mud* equivalent to one day of fasting.

Then Allah mentions that the purpose of the punishment that has been established is so that those who violate the prohibition can feel the consequences of their actions. Furthermore, Allah explains that He forgives past mistakes, namely, killing game animals while they were in *ihram* and done before the revelation of this verse.

At the end of this verse, Allah mentions His threat to those who still violate this prohibition after the revelation of this verse, namely, that He will punish them. Allah is All-Powerful and has the power to punish every guilty creature.
text.96:
In this verse, Allah explains that He has made lawful for the believers, whether in a state of *ihram* or not, to eat the meat of sea game, including animals from rivers, lakes, and so on, and that which is easily obtained, such as fish that have just died and are floating or fish that are stranded on the beach, and so on.

All of this is bestowed by Allah as delicious food for them and for those who are traveling. Then, Allah reaffirms that He has forbidden the believers from hunting land game while they are in a state of *ihram*.

At the end of the verse, He warns the believers to always be mindful of Allah, to whom they will be gathered on the Day of Judgment, to be held accountable for all their deeds and then be given rewards or punishments commensurate with those deeds.
text.97:
This verse explains that Allah has made the Ka'bah, the sacred house, as a center of activity for mankind, both for activities in worldly affairs, such as trade and so on, and for the activities of Hajj and Umrah for believers from all corners of the world.

Allah has established the sacred months "namely Dhu al-Qa'dah, Dhu al-Hijjah, Muharram and Rajab" which are peaceful times for worship and work for them, because during those months it is not permissible to wage war. Likewise, livestock such as camels, cows, goats and sheep that are slaughtered in the sacred land as gifts and distributed to the poor and needy, as well as animals that are collared, namely fat camels or goats to indicate that these animals have been designated as *hadyu* (sacrificial animals) to be slaughtered. Thus, the slaughter of these animals will certainly add to the splendor of the worship of the Muslims and will also be moments of happiness for the poor and needy. The believers do not feel worried about their safety at those times, because if they have collared the animals they will slaughter, or if they have worn *ihram* clothing, then no one will disturb or threaten their safety.

Then Allah explains that all of this is established so that His servants may know that He always knows what is in the heavens and on earth and that Allah is All-Knowing of everything. The proof is that Allah has established everything to bring benefit to them and to avoid disaster before it occurs. Thus, it is clear that Allah knows what is happening and what will happen. Based on His Vast Knowledge, Allah establishes His laws and regulations for the benefit of His servants.
text.98:
After Allah explained that all recompense for evil deeds is in His hands, and that He knows everything His servants do, Allah reaffirms the duty of His Messenger: to convey the message, namely to deliver His laws, regulations, and guidance, as well as His wa'd (promise) and wa'id (threat). Once all of this has been carried out by the Messenger, his duty is complete, and he is released from his responsibility, which then becomes the duty and responsibility of the believers. As for bestowing rewards upon those who are obedient, and inflicting punishment upon those who are disobedient, that is solely the right and authority of Allah.

At the end of this verse, Allah reaffirms that He always knows what people do openly, as well as what they do secretly, including the movements of their hearts. This is a stern warning from Allah to those who do not obey His regulations and laws. Therefore, it is fitting for mankind to be mindful of Him (taqwa) and not to violate His commands.
text.99:
After Allah explained that all recompense for evil deeds is in His hands, and that He knows everything His servants do, Allah reaffirms the duty of His Messenger: to convey the message, namely to convey His laws, regulations, and guidance, as well as His wa'd (promise) and wa'id (threat). Once all of this has been carried out by the Messenger, his duty is complete, and he is released from his responsibility, which then becomes the duty and responsibility of the believers. As for bestowing rewards upon those who are obedient, and inflicting punishment upon those who are disobedient, that is the sole right and authority of Allah.

At the end of this verse, Allah again affirms that He is always aware of what people do openly, as well as what they do secretly, including the movements of their hearts. This is a stern warning from Allah to those who do not obey His regulations and laws. Therefore, it is fitting for mankind to be mindful of Him (taqwa) and not to disobey His commands.
text.100:
In this verse, Allah commands His Messenger to explain the characteristics of actions and the people who perform them, which will cause them to obtain His reward or punishment. It is emphasized that evil and wickedness are not the same as virtue and good deeds. Good possessions or those obtained through lawful means are not the same as bad possessions or those obtained through unlawful means. Things that bring harm are not the same as things that are beneficial.

Likewise, the unjust are not the same as the just; and the wicked are not the same as the righteous; the disobedient are not the same as the obedient and pious. Each will receive a different assessment from Allah and will be given reward or punishment, according to their respective characteristics and conditions.

Then Allah warns His servants not to be deceived by seeing the abundance of bad deeds and things. Bad deeds are indeed very pleasing to those who are weak in faith. Especially in large cities where many people establish businesses that use various facilities that facilitate the occurrence of immorality. Likewise, bad and unlawful things are also very pleasing because they can be obtained easily, such as: *riba* (usury), gambling, bribery, theft, robbery, and so on.

But those who are strong in faith will not be deceived by all these temptations. No matter how many people around them commit these evils, they still adhere to the laws and guidance of their religion. The number of people like this may not be as many as those who tend towards evil and wickedness. But Allah does not judge by the quantity of numbers, but He judges His servants from the aspect of the goodness of their character and actions.

At the end of this verse, Allah directs His word to those who are of sound mind, who can distinguish between good and bad, between beneficial and harmful, so that they are not deceived by the various temptations of Satan who always wants to plunge humans into evil and misery. Steadfastness of faith in the midst of diverse immoralities is what will lead them to happiness and good fortune in this world and the hereafter.
text.101:
In this verse, Allah provides guidance to His servants, so that they accept what He has revealed and what His Messenger has conveyed to them, so that they do not ask various questions, because if the answers to those questions are given to them, it will feel burdensome to them, as it will be felt to add to their burden and obligations. Especially if the questions asked are intended to test the Prophet, whether the Qur'an is the same as or different from the holy books they have received, or they are even seeking relief from the various obligations that Allah has imposed.

Furthermore, this verse explains that if they ask the Prophet about something that is not yet clear when a verse related to that matter is revealed, and the question really needs to be answered to understand the content and meaning of the verse, then Allah permits it. In fact, we are told to ask if there is something we do not understand, as Allah says in Surah an-Nahl/16: 43:

And We sent not before you (O Muhammad) except men to whom We revealed [Our message]. So ask the people of the message if you do not know. (an-Nahl/16: 43)

The end of this verse affirms that Allah is Most Forgiving, Most Forbearing. The meaning is: Allah forgives those who ask truly beneficial questions, and things that are not mentioned in His Book, and things that He does not burden His servants with, and His prohibition to them not to ask the Messenger questions that are testing or mocking can add to the weight of their burden; this prohibition is a mercy from Him to His servants; in connection with this, the Messenger of Allah said:

Indeed, Allah has determined some obligations that you must fulfill, so do not neglect them; and He has forbidden you from doing some kinds of actions, so do not violate them; and He has established some limitations, so do not transgress them; and He has pardoned you from various things, not out of forgetfulness, so do not seek them out. (Narrated by ad-Daruquthni)

In connection with Allah's forgiveness mentioned in this verse, it can also be understood that Allah forgives the mistakes that were made before this prohibition, so that Allah does not inflict punishment, because of the vastness of His forgiveness and forbearance towards His servants. This is in accordance with His words in other verses, including:

Allah has pardoned what is past. (al-Ma'idah/5:95)
text.102: This verse reminds the Muslims that asking many questions about matters of religious law, as they are doing, has happened to previous nations. However, after they were given answers and explanations, they refused to implement them, even turning their backs on them because they considered them too burdensome. Then they denied those laws, or they said that those laws did not come from Allah. In any case, all of this constitutes disbelief (kufr), which deserves punishment, both in this world and in the hereafter.
text.103:
This verse affirms that Allah never decreed the prohibition of certain things that were practiced in the customs of Jahiliyyah, such as the prohibition of various animals, so they did not eat their meat. They themselves established the prohibition of eating the meat of these animals. But they said that the provision came from Allah. These animals are as follows:

a. Bahirah, which is a female camel that has given birth five times, and its fifth offspring is female. According to the customs of Jahiliyyah, such a female camel would have its ears split, then they would release it, and it was no longer allowed to be used for transportation, and its milk could not be taken.

b. Saibah, which is a female camel that is released to go wherever it wants, is not allowed to be used for transportation or carrying loads, and its wool is not allowed to be taken, nor is its milk allowed to be taken, except for guests. According to the customs of Jahiliyyah, this was done to fulfill a vow. If someone among them did a heavy job, or a long journey, then they vowed that they would make their camel a saibah if their work was successful, or their journey went safely.

c. Wasilah, which is a female goat or camel that is born as a twin with its male sibling. According to the customs of Jahiliyyah, if a female goat gave birth to twin male and female offspring, and the female had another female offspring, then her female offspring was called "wasilah", it was not allowed to be slaughtered, and it was not allowed to be offered to idols.

d. Ham, is a male camel that has served to impregnate a female camel ten times. According to the customs of Jahiliyyah, such a male camel was no longer allowed to be disturbed, for example, slaughtered, or used for any purpose, but had to be cared for properly. It could not be prevented from drinking water or eating grass wherever it liked.

These are some of the Jahiliyyah customs regarding various animals that were not allowed to be eaten. They said that the provision was from Allah, and became the law of religion. So in this verse, Allah refutes it, and affirms that the disbelievers themselves established the provision, thus, they have fabricated a lie against Allah.

Among the Indonesian Muslim community, this anthropological phenomenon that developed in the environment of the Jahiliyyah Arabs appears in the form of taboos, pamali (prohibitions), and others. Not a few certain prohibitions or taboos are so deeply rooted in Muslim society, even though the matter has absolutely no basis in religious teachings. These pamali things are solely the product of local traditions passed down from generation to generation whose truth is not supported by religion. The anthropological information conveyed by Allah in verses 103-104 of Surah al-Ma'idah/5 contains a very important lesson for Muslim communities everywhere not to continue to maintain taboos, because it is not forbidden by Allah. If such a thing continues, it means that the community has committed disobedience to Allah.

At the end of this verse, Allah explains that most of the disbelievers do not use their minds. Because, if they wanted to use their common sense, they would not make lies against Allah, and also would not prohibit what Allah has not prohibited.

According to a narration from Ibn Jarir, Abu Hurairah said, "I heard the Messenger of Allah say to Aktsam bin al-Jaun, "O Aktsam, hell has been shown to me, and I saw in hell Amru bin Luhay, Ibnu Qam'ah bin Khinzif pulling his intestines. So I did not see anyone other than you who looked more like him." Then Aktsam said, "I am afraid that my resemblance to him will bring some danger upon me." The Messenger of Allah replied, "No, because you are a believer, while he is a disbeliever; he is the first person to change the religion of Prophet Ismail, and he is the first person to establish provisions regarding bahirah, saibah, wasilah and ham."

From this narration, it can be understood that something that is fabricated in the law of religion, for example, prohibiting food that Allah has made lawful, or creating traditions that contradict religion, or holding worship that is not established by religion as a way to draw closer to Allah and obtain His pleasure, then this act is the same as the act of 'Amru bin Luhay. Whereas the valid ways to worship Allah have been determined by Him and have been conveyed by His Messenger. So every worship and determination of law must be based on the nash of the Al-Qur'an or the provisions of the Messenger. A person may not add or subtract according to his own will.
text.104:
This verse explains the stubborn attitude of the disbelievers. When they are invited to follow Allah's laws that are already in the Qur'an, reinforced with various reasons and clear proofs, and to follow the explanations conveyed by the Messenger of Allah, they reject it. They say that what they inherited from their ancestors is sufficient for them. Allah condemns their attitude and explains that they are not worthy of following any sharia, nor do they receive guidance from Allah to the straight path to achieve the benefit of this world and the hereafter.

Their ancestors were illiterate and still simple in their thinking, not yet having true knowledge that could distinguish between right and wrong. Their minds were still shrouded in false beliefs and superstitions, as well as ways of life that were not in accordance with humanity, for example: killing female children, engaging in wars and hostilities between tribes, looking down on orphans and women, and so on.

Regarding the attitude of the disbelievers like that, it is mentioned in another verse as follows:

And when it is said to them, "Follow what Allah has revealed," they say, "Rather, we will follow that which we found our fathers doing." Even though Satan was inviting them to the punishment of the Blaze? (Luqman/31: 21)
text.105:
After mentioning some characteristics of polytheists and disbelievers in the previous verses, in this verse Allah directs His word to the believers, warning them to guard against and distance themselves from such characteristics as: ignorance, disobedience, and so on. They must constantly improve themselves with strong faith, beneficial knowledge, and righteous deeds, remaining in Allah's guidance, by following the true sharia that has been revealed and conveyed by His Messenger. If they carry out this guidance, they can no longer be influenced by negative influences, no matter how bad the environmental situation in which they are. The sins and responsibilities of those who commit evil will not be charged to them, as long as they firmly adhere to Allah's guidance and direction.

Such personal steadfastness as described in this verse is very important for every believer, and needs to be continuously cultivated because many people who initially had faith, later their faith fades, due to the influence of their environment. This is because they do not follow Allah's guidance, and always follow the temptations of Satan.

Islam has shown us ways to build a strong personality and faith, including through worship and dhikr, constantly remembering Allah, and deepening knowledge about religion. If a person constantly remembers Allah, and he realizes that Allah will reward all his deeds, then he will be able to stay away from actions that Allah forbids, and he will always do actions that please Him.
text.106:
This verse explains that if a believer feels the need to make a will regarding their property, then the will must be witnessed by two believers who are just and have firm principles. This is so that if problems arise in the future that require their testimony, it can be expected that they will give truthful testimony and will not conceal anything they know about the will.

It is then explained that if two believing witnesses are not available, for example, when the person making the will is traveling and then encounters a misfortune and feels their death is near, then they may take two witnesses who are not believers, but who must be just and have firm principles.

The two people who will be made witnesses are asked to wait until after prayer. The scholars say that "after prayer" means "after Asr prayer." This is based on what the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) used to do, and this custom also applies among Muslims, because at those times there are many people who will witness it, because most of them have finished most of the tasks that are usually done during the day. At that time, the judge usually holds a session to examine the cases submitted to him. If the two witnesses are not believers, then what is meant by prayer is the prayer performed according to their religion.

If the two witnesses are trustworthy enough, then their testimony regarding the will does not need to be accompanied by an oath. But if the heirs of the person making the will doubt the honesty of the witnesses, then the witnesses are asked to take an oath to strengthen their testimony, so that it can be expected that they will truly act as honest and fully trustworthy witnesses.

The wording of the oath must be spoken by the two witnesses based on the following verse:

"By Allah, we will not exchange our oath for a price, even for a relative, nor will we conceal the testimony of Allah. Indeed, we would then be of the sinful." (al-Ma'idah/5: 106)

The content of the oath shows that the witnesses pledge not to treat the testimony like merchandise that can be traded. They do not conceal the testimony or change it because they want to expect something for personal gain. They will always uphold their testimony even if it causes harm to one of their relatives. They are absolutely sure that if they conceal their testimony when that testimony is needed, or change it with false testimony, they will certainly sin and will receive punishment from Allah.
text.107:
Furthermore, this verse explains that if, in the future, after the death of the testator, signs of dishonesty appear in the witnesses, for example, when asked for their testimony they give untrue testimony, or claim not to have concealed anything from the inheritance entrusted to them by the testator, then to find a resolution in that situation, the obligation to swear an oath is transferred to the heirs of the deceased who made the will. For this, two other people must be found who are closest in family relationship to the testator, namely those who are most entitled to receive the inheritance, if they meet the requirements to be able to receive the inheritance. Such as not being of a different religion or not being involved in the case of the testator's murder.

If the closest relatives do not meet the requirements to be able to receive the inheritance, for example, because of a difference in religion with the person leaving the inheritance, or because they are involved in the case of the testator's murder, then two other people should be sought among the heirs who are most worthy to take the oath, considering their age, character, knowledge, and so on.

The oath spoken by these two heirs is intended to strengthen the accusation against the two people who received the will, that they have betrayed the will. It is also to confirm that they are correct in making the accusation, and are not exceeding the limits; meaning: the accusation is not a random and unfounded accusation. It is also concluded with a reaffirmation that if they make false accusations or testimony, then they will certainly be among the wrongdoers.

In another verse, the position of the witness, which was initially obligatory, then becomes sunnah, is explained.

"It is prescribed for you when death approaches [any] one of you if he leaves wealth [that he should make] a bequest for parents and near relatives according to what is acceptable - a duty upon the righteous." (al-Baqarah/2: 180)
text.108:
In this verse, it is explained that the method and content of the oath as mentioned above is a path closer to the truth, which can encourage those who take the oath (both the recipients of the will and the heirs of the one who made the oath) to give true testimony, full of responsibility, and to glorify Allah (whose name is mentioned in their oath), and to be more careful in preserving the will and testimony so as to avoid the punishment and wrath of Allah, and so that the oath is not transferred to another person due to dishonesty.

At the end of this verse, Allah warns His servants to be mindful of Him, to uphold trust and testimony, and to be willing to listen to and pay attention to all His guidance and provisions, and then to implement them in the best possible way. Allah also warns about the habits of the wicked, namely those who do not want to uphold truth and justice; they will not receive true guidance.

It needs to be explained that after the two heirs have taken the oath, which is intended to declare the dishonesty of the two recipients of the will, then the inheritance left by the person who made the will is handed over entirely to the heirs, for them to distribute according to their respective shares, in addition to carrying out the actual will and debts and other obligations.
text.109:
This verse explains that on the Day of Judgment, Allah will gather the messengers and their respective communities. The day this event occurs is called "Yaumul Mahsyar." At that time, Allah will ask the messengers, "What response did they receive from their communities after they called them to His religion?"

The messengers certainly know what answers they received from their respective communities, and how they responded to the calls that were conveyed to them, although they do not know everything. However, the messengers are people of very high character and are very humble before Allah, the Almighty and All-Knowing of everything. Therefore, with a full sense of servitude to Allah, they answer, "That they have no knowledge of it. Indeed, Allah is the Knower of the unseen."

Allah asks the messengers what response they received from the communities they called to His religion. Allah does not ask the messengers whether they have conveyed the message entrusted to them, or not? This shows that the messengers have truly carried out their duties well, namely conveying the religion of Allah to their people. However, some of those people did not accept the invitation and call in the best possible way.

Another thing we can understand from this verse is that Allah does not directly ask questions to the communities of the messengers, for example: "O people, what answer did you give to My messengers when they conveyed My message to you?" Instead, Allah conveys His questions to His messengers, not to their communities. This shows Allah's wrath towards the communities that ignored the calls and warnings that the messengers had conveyed to them. So the question is to rebuke the disobedient communities.
text.110:
This verse explains the various blessings bestowed upon Prophet Isa (Jesus) and his mother, and then reveals again the various evils of the Children of Israel who once accused that the various explanations and proofs conveyed by Prophet Isa to them were merely magic.

Allah's blessing upon Maryam (Mary), the mother of Prophet Isa, is that Allah made her a holy woman, chosen among the women of the world to obtain a noble position.

The blessings of Allah to Prophet Isa mentioned in this verse are as follows:

1. Allah strengthened Prophet Isa with the Holy Spirit (Rohulkudus), namely the angel Gabriel. Allah made his soul pure from all bad qualities. With this blessing, Isa could know that he was born into the world with an extraordinary event, so that he could prove his purity and the purity of his mother. Because Allah had strengthened him with the Holy Spirit, he could speak when he was still small and weak, still in the cradle. He spoke to defend the purity and honor of his mother against unfounded accusations from the Jews. Then, after he grew up, he could also speak well to call people to the religion of Allah.

Regarding Prophet Isa, his mother, and the Holy Spirit in this verse, the opinions of several commentators can be said to be the same. Regarding "remembering the blessings," it means "being grateful" for the blessings given to Isa and to his mother Maryam and strengthening him with the Holy Spirit, namely Gabriel, and speaking with people when he was still a baby and after becoming an adult Prophet, who, according to Ibn 'Abbas as quoted by al-Bagawi, at the age of 30 and carrying out his prophetic duties for 30 months. Then "I taught you writing, wisdom (namely the wisdom of knowledge), the Torah and the Gospel," and so on. For more on the Holy Spirit, see the vocabulary above (al-Baqarah/2: 253). It can be added that, as mentioned in the Qur'an, the Holy Spirit applies to all believers (al-Mujadalah/58: 22); and is sent down to whomever He wills from His servants according to His will. In this verse, ruh means revelation (al-Kahf/16: 2).

Prophet Isa calls himself the son of Maryam, who does not know a human father because his birth was indeed a miracle. Allah has given him a great blessing in the form of spiritual strength, "strengthening him with the Holy Spirit," with the miracles that occurred around him and his mother Maryam, regarding his birth, life, and death.

But the Holy Spirit (al-Baqarah/2: 87) that we often encounter in the Qur'an, in the sense of "holy spirit" also means "divine inspiration." Prophet Muhammad also prayed for mercy with the Holy Spirit to a companion, namely the poet Hassan bin Thabit through his words:

That Hassan bin Thabit al-Ansari asked Abu Hurairah for testimony, "Did you hear the Prophet Saw say, "O Hassan, fulfill the Messenger of Allah. O Allah, strengthen him (Hassan) with the Holy Spirit." (Narrated by al-Bukhari, Muslim, and an-Nasa'i)

The meaning of the Holy Spirit in the Qur'an and hadith is not the same as the meaning of the Holy Spirit in the Bible (Old Testament and New Testament). The Spirit, the Spirit of God or His word in the Old Testament (Genesis i.2) is about the formation of the earth, "and the Spirit of God was hovering over the surface of the water," and Psalm xxxiii.6, "By the word of the Lord the heavens were made, by the breath of His mouth¦" In the New Testament it is called the Holy Spirit, the Spirit of God or the Spirit of Jesus. Matthew mentions that the birth of Jesus Christ when Mary was betrothed to Joseph, the son of Heli, conceived of the Holy Spirit, before they lived as husband and wife. Joseph, Mary's husband, was a sincere man, he did not want to defame his wife's name in public, he intended to divorce her secretly. But in his dream, an angel of the Lord appeared to him, and said, do not be afraid "¦ to take Mary as your wife, because the child in her womb is the Holy Spirit. She will give birth to a son and you will name Him Jesus, ¦" (Matthew 1.18-21). See also the vocabulary (an-Nisa'/4: 156).

2. Allah taught him the Book, meaning Isa was granted the ability to write and read, so that he could study written knowledge. In addition to that, Allah also taught him the Torah, namely the holy book that had been revealed to Prophet Musa (Moses). Finally, Allah taught him the Gospel, namely the holy book that was revealed to Prophet Isa himself.

Prophet Isa himself never changed the contents of the Torah and did not replace it with the Gospel that was revealed to him, and it is acknowledged by the current New Testament, "Do not think that I have come to abolish the Law or the Prophets; I have not come to abolish them but to fulfill them." (Matthew v.17).

3. Isa could make from clay something whose shape and size was like a bird, then he blew on the bird, and it became a real bird, with the permission of Allah. Meaning, Isa is the one who formed the object like a bird, and he is also the one who blew on it, then Allah made it a living bird.

4. Isa was able to heal the blind from birth and those who had leprosy, with the permission of Allah, even though at that time no doctor could cure the blind from birth and those who had leprosy.

In Indonesian, the word abras is equated with leprosy from the English translation leprosy, namely "a chronic disease that attacks the skin and nerves, which slowly causes damage to the limbs; leprosy" (Kamus Besar Bahasa Indonesia), which in Arabic is usually equated with judzam, not abras. Mu'jam Alfadh al-Qur'an al-Karim explains that abras "is a white color on the skin due to the loss of red pigment and causes white spots in various forms. This is a symptom of leprosy." So it's not leprosy. In the New Testament (Matthew x.8, Luke iv.27), it is translated as "leprosy," the same as the English translation. In this Tafsir it is translated as "sopak," which seems more appropriate, namely "a skin disease in the form of white patches on the hands or feet due to pigment cells are cells that give the skin color dry, tan." (Kamus Besar Bahasa Indonesia), or in medical terms known as leukemia or vitiligo.

5. Isa could also bring the dead back to life, so that they could come out of their graves alive, with the permission of Allah.

After Prophet Isa gave evidence with his miracles, some of them (the Children of Israel) accused him of performing magic, casting out demons by using the leader of the demons, "He is driving out demons by Beelzebul, the prince of demons" (Luke xi.15).

The Jews called the king of demons or the prince of demons Beelzebul, and the prince of demons used to cast out demons is found in several chapters in the New Testament, including in Matthew, Mark and Luke.

6. Allah has protected Prophet Isa from the evil of the Jews who wanted to kill and crucify him, when Isa came to them bringing the religion of Allah accompanied by clear evidence and explanations, which Allah had bestowed upon him. Allah saved Isa and raised him to Himself.

The evil of the Children of Israel exceeded the evil of other people, the evil of other people towards the messenger of Allah was only limited to the person of the messenger, but the evil of the Children of Israel was not only directed at Prophet Isa alone, but also at his mother, namely they accused Maryam of committing adultery with a man, so that she gave birth to Isa. In fact, their evil was not only directed at Isa and his mother, but also at Allah, because they said that Allah had a wife and children, even though Allah is Most Holy from such things.

The disbelievers among the Children of Israel not only rejected the religion of Allah that Prophet Isa conveyed to them, but they even said that the explanations that Isa conveyed were merely magic.

The various blessings of Allah to Prophet Isa mentioned in this verse are a very sharp insinuation and reproach against the Children of Israel, for their heinous attitudes and actions. This verse also reveals how great their envy is towards those who receive Allah's blessings. Their statement that the explanations that Prophet Isa conveyed to them were "obvious magic" is strong evidence of their envious nature towards Prophet Isa who had been chosen by Allah as His Prophet and Messenger.

The blessing of Allah to Prophet Isa mentioned in this verse is an extraordinary blessing, which Allah did not give to other prophets. In the next verse, Allah mentions some of His other blessings that He also gave to Prophet Isa but are ordinary blessings, which other messengers also obtained.
text.111:
Allah explains the attitude of the hawariyin, a group from the Children of Israel who readily accepted the religion of Allah conveyed by Prophet Isa. They then said to Prophet Isa, "We have believed; and bear witness that we are Muslims [submitting to Allah]." Meaning, they believed and accepted the call of Prophet Isa, and would carry out all his commands, as proof of that faith.

The meaning of Allah's favor upon Prophet Isa in this matter is that Prophet Isa received a good reception from the hawariyin, so that they loved and obeyed him. This is not only a favor for Prophet Isa alone, but also a favor for his mother, because every favor obtained by a child also brings joy and happiness to his mother.
text.112:
In this verse, Allah recounts that the *hawariyyin* once asked Prophet Isa, "Is your Lord able to send down to us a table spread with food from heaven?" This question did not indicate that the *hawariyyin* still doubted Allah's power. They were fully convinced of Allah's power. But they asked this to further reassure their hearts. Because, if they could witness that Allah was able to send down what they desired, then their hearts would be more at peace, and their faith would become stronger.

This also happened to Prophet Ibrahim when he asked Allah to show him how He is able to bring the dead back to life. Allah said:

"And [mention] when Abraham said, "My Lord, show me how You give life to the dead." [Allah] said, "Have you not believed?" He said, "Yes, but [I ask] only that my heart may be satisfied." (al-Baqarah/2:260)

Thus, the question of the *hawariyyin* can be interpreted as follows, "O Isa, would your Lord allow it if we asked Him to send down to us a table spread with food?" So what they doubted was not Allah's power to grant this, but whether God would be willing to grant the Prophet's request, if Prophet Isa asked Him for it on their behalf. It should be noted in the verse above that when the *hawariyyin* posed their question to Prophet Isa, they mentioned him by name, followed by the title 'son of Maryam.' This was to emphasize that they did not adhere to the belief that Isa was God, or the son of God. They believed that Isa was a creature of Allah chosen to be His Prophet and Messenger, and also the son of Maryam, not the son of Allah.

*hawariyyun* or *hawariyyin*, from the word *hawari*, "a bleaching agent for clothes, which is clean and free from all stains; companion and defender;" according to *Mu'jam Alfadh al-Qur'an al-Karim*, *hawari*, "pure and clean from everything, generally used for those who are truly sincere to the prophets," or "defense, support," "defenders" (Ali 'Imran/3: 52). Possibly from Abyssinian origin. According to Muhammad Asad in *The Message of The Qur'an*, "one who whitens his clothes by washing them," hence it is also said for the followers of Prophet Isa as a symbol of people with pure hearts. The recent discovery of the Dead Sea Scrolls strongly supports this view, that the word *hawari* was used to refer to members of the Essene Brotherhood, a religious group in Palestine during the time of Prophet Isa, which may have included him himself. The Essenes were especially known for their persistence in maintaining moral purity and selflessness, and they always wore white clothes. Prophet Muhammad gave the title *hawari* to Zubair bin 'Awwam by saying:

"Every prophet has a *hawari*, and my *hawari* is Zubair bin 'Awwam." (Riwayat al-Bukhari and at-Tirmidzi)

In some Indonesian *tafsir*, it is translated as "followers," "companions," "helpers," or "steadfast *Hawariyun*;" while the Bible translates it as "disciples."

At the end of the verse, the answer of Prophet Isa to the *hawariyyin* is explained. He ordered them to fear Allah, that is, not to make requests or questions that give the impression that they doubt Allah's power. This is a very good lesson, because those who believe must strengthen their faith, and eliminate all things that can reduce faith. Allah is All-Powerful over everything. Providing a table spread with food is not a proper thing to ask of Allah. He is Most Glorious. He has bestowed upon His servants everything on earth, whether in the form of food, clothing, housing, and so on. So it is the duty of humans to process the available materials to make them into food, clothing, houses and so on for their own benefit. Allah does not ask for compensation for the blessings He has provided, which are countless. If Allah does not send down food from heaven, then it does not diminish the meaning of His power and love for His servants. Therefore, do not diminish faith and belief in Him.
text.113: In this verse, the words of the disciples (hawariyyin) to Prophet Isa are recounted, after Isa commanded them to believe in Allah, to do good deeds, to work and to put their trust in Him, and not to make unreasonable requests. The disciples said, "We believe fully in the power of Allah, but we are making this request because we need food, and we have no other food, while we are hungry. Besides, if we can witness the descent of the food, and taste its deliciousness, then our faith will become stronger. Thus, we will also be able to be witnesses to those who did not witness the descent of the food and did not partake of it, so that they too will believe, and their conviction will also increase, because of our testimony."
text.114:
In this verse, it is explained that Prophet Isa, after understanding the good intentions of the *hawariyyin* (disciples) in their request – that they did not doubt Allah's power, but rather wanted to be more certain and gain stronger faith and peace of mind – granted their request to pray to Allah to send down a feast for them. Prophet Isa began his prayer with the words "Allahuma Rabbana." These words contain the understanding of His attributes of greatness, namely: divinity, power, wisdom, and His attributes as the Ruler, Educator, Sustainer, and Giver of blessings.

Then Isa continued his prayer with a request that Allah send down for them a feast from the sky. Prophet Isa hoped that the day when the feast descended would become a day of celebration for them and their future generations. This would also be a sign or proof of Allah's power. Prophet Isa ended his prayer with the words, "Provide us with sustenance, for You are the Best of Providers." What we need to pay attention to in this verse is that Prophet Isa, in his prayer, first mentioned the spiritual benefits that would be obtained if Allah granted his prayer, and only then were the physical benefits mentioned. The spiritual benefit is: the descent of the feast would be a very important day in the lives of his people, and they would make it a day of celebration, where they would always remember Allah's mercy, and they would glorify the greatness of His power. This will increase their certainty and strengthen their faith in Allah. As for the physical benefit, the food would be a sustenance that would eliminate hunger and restore their physical freshness and strength.

It was different with the *hawariyyin* when they made that request to Isa. They mentioned the physical benefits first, and only then did they mention the spiritual benefits. Thus, it can be concluded that with the structure of his prayer, Prophet Isa taught his people to prioritize the mental and spiritual aspects over the physical and material aspects.

The word "Ma'idah" is mentioned in this surah, which means "feast," so the word has been agreed upon as the name for this surah, namely Surah al-Ma'idah/5. The words used as names for the surahs of the Al-Qur'an are mostly taken from a word found in the surah concerned, which relates to something very important, for example: the name of this surah and Surah "al-Baqarah." Sometimes it is also taken from other words that are not found in the surah but clearly indicate the content of the surah, for example the name Surah al-Ikhlas/112.

Verses 112 and 113 mention the request for a feast of food from the sky by the followers of Prophet Isa. In several chapters of the New Testament, it is depicted in various ways (Matthew vi.11, Acts x.9-12, etc.).
text.115:
In this verse, it is explained that Allah granted their prayer and sent down the feast according to their request. However, with the condition that after the feast was sent down, none of them should remain disbelievers, or revert to disbelief after having believed, because they had been given lessons and explanations about the power and greatness of Allah, and then given concrete proof that they could witness with their own senses. If there were still among them who disbelieved, then it was fitting that the wrath and punishment of Allah be inflicted upon them, exceeding the punishment inflicted upon other disbelievers.

The opinions of the scholars vary regarding the type of food that Allah sent down in the feast. But this matter is not an important issue to discuss, as the Qur'an itself does not mention it. Likewise, the Prophet Muhammad (saw). What we need to pay attention to is the cause-and-effect relationship, as well as the content and purpose of the story, to be taken as a lesson and instruction to strengthen our faith and conviction in Allah with all His attributes of perfection.
text.116:
In this verse, Allah says, whether Isa and his mother had declared themselves as gods. Isa declares that the above statement is untrue, because he has no right to declare something that is not appropriate for himself and his mother. Allah asks this of Isa even though Allah knows what actually happened, so that Isa on the Day of Judgment can declare before the prophets and mankind that only Allah has the right to be worshipped, and he explains the error of his people who consider him and his mother as God. All worship is directed only to Allah. This verse provides a warning to Christians who live later about the errors and mistakes of their creed. Many kinds of worship and prayers performed by Christians are directed to Isa and his mother, both specifically for Isa and his mother respectively, and worship associating them with Allah. All such worship cannot be justified, because all worship must be directed to Allah alone. Allah says:

"Whereas they were commanded no more than to worship Allah, offering Him sincere devotion, being true (in faith);..." (al-Bayyinah/98: 5)

There is no god but Allah who deserves to be worshipped by servants. Prophet Isa answered Allah's question about the worship and belief directed to him and his mother with an answer that began with the word "Subhanaka" meaning "Glory be to You", meaning it is impossible for there to be a god besides Allah.

Prophet Isa affirmed that neither himself nor anyone else has the right to say something that is not appropriate for himself and his mother. It never crossed Prophet Isa's mind to declare himself or his mother as gods, because he was sent to mankind to guide them to the straight path, namely the religion of *tauhid* (monotheism). If Prophet Isa had declared his recognition as God, or it had crossed his mind, then Allah would have known it better, because He is the All-Knowing of what is hidden in human thoughts, especially what is revealed. Humans do not know what Allah hides unless He informs them through revelation. Indeed, only Allah Himself is the All-Knowing of all that is unseen; His knowledge encompasses everything that has happened, is happening, and will happen.

Allah asks whether Prophet Isa declared himself and his mother as God, because many Christians in Najran considered Isa and his mother as God (Alusi V;94). Importantly, this verse is Prophet Isa's answer which clearly states that he never declared himself and his mother as God. This answer needs to be known by Prophet Isa's disciples and all his followers.
text.117:
After Prophet Isa (Jesus) in the previous verse sanctified Allah and then cleared himself of the accusation of considering himself God, in this verse Isa explains what he actually called his people to, namely to worship Allah, his Lord and also their Lord. It is not true that he deified himself and his mother because they are both servants of Allah just like other humans. Prophet Isa taught the main points of religion and the foundations of faith to his people, which they should have made a guide in their religious life for all time. While Prophet Isa was still with them, he always gave guidance to them and supervised all their behavior; what was right was justified, what was wrong was declared wrong according to Allah's guidance. But after he was raised to heaven, his period of apostleship ended, his supervision and guidance over his people ceased. Prophet Isa no longer knew their deeds and the history of their development and their religion. Only Allah is the Overseer and Witness over them. Allah gives guidance to those who desire truth, and leaves those who desire error. Those who deify Isa have disbelieved and Paradise is forbidden to them. This is affirmed by Allah in His word:

"Indeed, those who say, "Allah is the Messiah, the son of Mary" have disbelieved. The Messiah [himself] said, "O Children of Israel, worship Allah, my Lord and your Lord." Indeed, he who associates others with Allah - Allah has forbidden him Paradise, and his abode is the Fire. And there are not for the wrongdoers any helpers." (al-Ma'idah/5:72)
text.118:
This verse explains that Jesus completely surrendered the decision regarding the Christians to Allah, and he disavowed responsibility for their actions, because he had conveyed his call in accordance with Allah's command, which is to single Him out and dedicate worship solely to Him. Allah will inflict punishment upon them according to their deeds. He knows who among them remains in *tauhid* (monotheism) and who is a *mushrik* (polytheist), who is obedient and who is disbelieving, who is righteous and who is wicked. If Allah inflicts punishment upon them, then that punishment falls upon those who truly deserve to receive it. They are the servants of Allah; they should worship Allah and not worship anything besides Allah. If Allah grants forgiveness to them, then that forgiveness is given to those who deserve it and are worthy of receiving it. Allah is All-Powerful and has authority in managing all affairs; no one else participates in managing them. Allah is All-Wise in determining decisions regarding that matter, and He is All-Knowing as to who among the Christians has become a *mushrik* and who remains in the religion of *tauhid*.

For those who become *mushrik*, there is no forgiveness for their sins. Allah says:

"Indeed, Allah does not forgive association with Him (shirk), but He forgives what is less than that for whom He wills." (an-Nisa'/4: 48)

Since the beginning of the Common Era, many different schools of thought have grown among the followers of Christianity. Consequently, many disputes have arisen among them, so everything is left to Allah to punish or forgive among His servants according to His will.
text.119: In this verse, Allah explains that on the Day of Judgment, those who consistently maintain monotheism (tauhid), will benefit from the truth of their faith and from the sincerity of their actions and words. The benefits they will receive are: first, the pleasures of Paradise, pleasures that greatly satisfy the physical body, and second, the pleasure of divine pleasure (rida Ilahi), a pleasure that provides tranquility and spiritual satisfaction. All their deeds are accepted by Allah as worship, and Allah bestows grace and approval upon them. They feel happy to receive the pleasure of Allah. There is no greater pleasure than the appreciation from Allah. Allah is pleased with them, and they are pleased with Allah. This is the peak of eternal happiness within a human being. These two blessings of Allah are Paradise and divine pleasure (rida Ilahi) which are obtained after passing the reckoning of deeds on the Day of Judgment.
text.120: This surah concludes with the declaration that all the kingdoms of the heavens and the earth, along with their contents, belong solely to Allah. Both intelligent and unintelligent creatures; inanimate objects and living beings, all are subject and subservient to His power and will (kudrat and iradat). This verse warns the Christians about the error of their way of thinking regarding Isa (Jesus) and his mother, who are considered gods, whereas both are servants of Allah and His property. Neither of them is a partner to Allah, nor His equal. Therefore, prayers and worship should not be directed to them. Only Allah is worthy of worship, because He is the owner and ruler of this universe and all that it contains.
